    12→confidence: medium
    13→description: Choose the best Redis data type for your task.
    14→id: 8d8f4284
    15→ingested_at: '2026-02-14T15:01:27Z'
    16→linkTitle: Compare data types
    17→source_commit: a9ff1a3
    18→source_path: content/develop/data-types/compare-data-types.md
    19→source_repo: https://github.com/redis/docs
    20→title: Compare data types
    21→weight: 1
    22→---
    23→
    24→Redis provides a wide range of data types to store your data.
    25→The following are highly specialized for precise purposes:
    26→
    27→-   [Geospatial]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/geospatial" >}}):
    28→    store strings with associated coordinates for geospatial queries.
    29→-   [Vector sets]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/vector-sets" >}}):
    30→    store strings with associated vector data (and optional metadata)
    31→    for vector similarity queries.
    32→-   [Probabilistic data types]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/probabilistic" >}}):
    33→    keep approximate counts and other statistics for large datasets.
    34→-   [Time series]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/timeseries" >}}):
    35→    store real-valued data points along with the time they were collected.
    36→
    37→The remaining data types are more general-purpose:
    38→
    39→-   [Strings]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/strings" >}}):
    40→    store text or binary data.
    41→-   [Hashes]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/hashes" >}}):
    42→    store key-value pairs within a single key.
    43→-   [JSON]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/json" >}}):
    44→    store structured, hierarchical arrays and key-value objects that match
    45→    the popular [JSON](https://www.json.org/json-en.html) text file format.
    46→-   [Lists]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/lists" >}}):
    47→    store a simple sequence of strings.
    48→-   [Sets]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/sets" >}}):
    49→    store a collection of unique strings.
    50→-   [Sorted sets]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/sorted-sets" >}}):
    51→    store a collection of unique strings with associated scores.
    52→-   [Streams]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/streams" >}}):
    53→    store a sequence of entries, each with a set of field-value pairs.
    54→
    55→The general-purpose data types have some overlap among their features
    56→and indeed, you could probably emulate any of them using just strings
    57→and a little creativity. However, each data type provides different
    58→tradeoffs in terms of performance, memory usage, and functionality.
    59→This guide helps you choose the best data type for your task.
    60→
    61→## Data type features
    62→
    63→The sections below summarize the features of each data type.
    64→
    65→### Strings
    66→
    67→-   **Structure**: unstructured text/binary data or simple counters,
    68→    bit sets, or integer collections.
    69→-   **Operations**: get, set, append, increment, decrement, bitwise operations.
    70→-   **Suitable for**: Unstructured documents, counters, flags, bitmaps.
    71→
    72→Strings are mainly useful for storing text or binary data chunks
    73→whose internal structure will be managed by your own application.
    74→However, they also support operations to access ranges of bits
    75→in the string to use as bit sets, integers, or floating-point numbers.
    76→
    77→
    78→### Hashes
    79→
    80→-   **Structure**: collection of key-value pairs.
    81→-   **Operations**: get, set, delete, increment, decrement, query.
    82→-   **Suitable for**: Simple objects with a small number of fields.
    83→
    84→Hashes are mainly useful for storing objects with a small number of fields
    85→that are not nested or intricately structured. However, there is
    86→no real limit to the number of fields you can store in a hash, so you
    87→can use hashes in many different ways inside your application.
    88→The field values are strings, but hashes provide commands to treat
    89→them as integers or floating-point numbers and perform simple arithmetic
    90→operations on them. You can set expirations on individual hash fields
    91→and you can also index and query hash documents using the Redis
    92→[query engine]({{< relref "/develop/ai/search-and-query" >}}).
    93→
    94→### JSON
    95→
    96→-   **Structure**: hierarchical arrays and key-value objects that match
    97→    the popular [JSON](https://www.json.org/json-en.html) text file format.
    98→-   **Operations**: get, set, update, delete, query.
    99→-   **Suitable for**: Complex, nested objects with many fields.
   100→
   101→JSON provides rich data modeling capabilities with nested fields and arrays.
   102→You can use a simple path syntax to access any subset of the data within
   103→a JSON document. JSON also has more powerful and flexible
   104→[query engine]({{< relref "/develop/ai/search-and-query" >}})
   105→features compared to hashes.
   106→
   107→### Lists
   108→
   109→-   **Structure**: simple sequence of strings.
   110→-   **Operations**: push, pop, get, set, trim.
   111→-   **Suitable for**: Queues, stacks, logs, and other linear data structures.
   112→
   113→Lists store sequences of string values. They are optimized for
   114→adding and removing small numbers of elements at the head or tail,
   115→and so they are very efficient for implementing queues, stacks,
   116→and deques.
   117→
   118→### Sets
   119→
   120→-   **Structure**: collection of unique strings.
   121→-   **Operations**: add, remove, test membership, intersect, union, difference.
   122→-   **Suitable for**: Unique items with no associated data.
   123→
   124→Sets store collections of unique strings. They provide efficient
   125→operations for testing membership, adding and removing elements.
   126→They also support set operations like intersection, union, and difference.
   127→
   128→### Sorted sets
   129→
   130→-   **Structure**: collection of unique strings with associated scores.
   131→-   **Operations**: add, remove, test membership, range by score or rank.
   132→-   **Suitable for**: Unique items with a score, or ordered collections.
   133→
   134→Sorted sets store collections of unique strings with associated scores.
   135→They are optimized for efficient range queries based on the score,
   136→and so they are useful for implementing priority queues and other ordered
   137→collections.
   138→
   139→### Streams
   140→
   141→-   **Structure**: sequence of entries, each with a set of field-value pairs.
   142→-   **Operations**: add, read, trim.
   143→-   **Suitable for**: Log data, time series, and other append-only structures.
   144→
   145→Streams store sequences of entries, each with a set of field-value pairs.
   146→They are optimized for appending new entries and reading them in order,
   147→and so they are useful for implementing log data, time series, and other
   148→append-only data structures. They also have built-in support for consumer groups
   149→to manage multiple readers and ensure at-least-once delivery.
   150→
   151→## Choose a data type
   152→
   153→The sections below explore the pros and cons of each data type for
   154→particular tasks. Note that you should regard
   155→the suggestions as "rules-of-thumb" rather than strict prescriptions, since
   156→there are potentially many subtle reasons to prefer one data type over another.
   157→
   158→### Documents
   159→
   160→You would normally store document data using the string, hash, or JSON
   161→types. JSON generally has the highest requirements for memory and processing,
   162→followed by hashes, and then strings. Use the decision tree below as a guide to
   163→choosing the best data type for your task.
   164→
   165→```decision-tree {id="documents-tree"}
   166→id: documents-tree
   167→scope: documents
   168→rootQuestion: root
   169→questions:
   170→    root:
   171→        text: |
   172→            Do you need nested data structures (fields and arrays) or geospatial
   173→            index/query with Redis query engine?
   174→        whyAsk: |
   175→            JSON is the only document type that supports deeply nested structures and integrates with the query engine for those structures
   176→        answers:
   177→            yes:
   178→                value: "Yes"
   179→                outcome:
   180→                    label: "Use JSON"
   181→                    id: jsonOutcome
   182→            no:
   183→                value: "No"
   184→                nextQuestion: hashQuestion
   185→    hashQuestion:
   186→        text: |
   187→            Do you need to index/query using Redis query engine but can live
   188→            without nested data structures and geospatial indexing?
   189→        whyAsk: |
   190→            Hashes support indexing and querying with lower memory overhead and faster field access than JSON
   191→        answers:
   192→            yes:
   193→                value: "Yes"
   194→                outcome:
   195→                    label: "Use hashes"
   196→                    id: hashOutcome
   197→            no:
   198→                value: "No"
   199→                nextQuestion: expirationQuestion
   200→    expirationQuestion:
   201→        text: |
   202→            Do you need to set expiration times on individual pieces of data
   203→            within the document?
   204→        whyAsk: "Only hashes support efficient field-level access and expiration"
   205→        answers:
   206→            yes:
   207→                value: "Yes"
   208→                outcome:
   209→                    label: "Use hashes"
   210→                    id: hashOutcome
   211→            no:
   212→                value: "No"
   213→                nextQuestion: fieldAccessQuestion
   214→    fieldAccessQuestion:
   215→        text: |
   216→            Do you need frequent access to individual data fields within the
   217→            document, but the fields are simple integers or bits that you can easily 
   218→            refer to by an integer index?
   219→        whyAsk: |
   220→            Strings and hashes support efficient field access, but strings are more compact and efficient if you only need bit fields with integer indices
   221→        answers:
   222→            yes:
   223→                value: "Yes"
   224→                outcome:
   225→                    label: "Use strings"
   226→                    id: stringOutcome
   227→            no:
   228→                value: "No"
   229→                nextQuestion: stringQuestion
   230→    stringQuestion:
   231→        text: |
   232→            Do you need frequent access to individual data fields within the
   233→            document that have string or binary data values?
   234→        whyAsk: |
   235→            Hashes support general field access, but strings are more compact and efficient if you don't need it
   236→        answers:
   237→            yes:
   238→                value: "Yes"
   239→                outcome:
   240→                    label: "Use hashes"
   241→                    id: hashOutcome
   242→            no:
   243→                value: "No"
   244→                outcome:
   245→                    label: "Use strings"
   246→                    id: stringOutcome
   247→```
   248→
   249→### Collections
   250→
   251→You would normally store collection data using the set or sorted set
   252→types and for very simple collections, you can even use strings. They all allow
   253→basic membership tests, but have different additional features and tradeoffs.
   254→Sorted sets have the highest memory overhead and processing requirements, followed
   255→by sets, and then strings.
   256→Use the decision tree below as a guide to choosing the best data type for your task.
   257→Note that if you need to store extra information for the keys in a set
   258→or sorted set, you can do so with an auxiliary hash or JSON object that has field
   259→names matching the keys in the collection.
   260→
   261→```decision-tree {id="collections-tree"}
   262→id: collections-tree
   263→scope: collections
   264→rootQuestion: root
   265→questions:
   266→    root:
   267→        text: |
   268→            Do you need to store and retrieve the keys in an arbitrary order or in
   269→            lexicographical order?
   270→        whyAsk: |
   271→            Sorted sets are the only collection type that supports ordered iteration,
   272→            which is essential if you need to access elements in a specific order
   273→        answers:
   274→            yes:
   275→                value: "Yes"
   276→                outcome:
   277→                    label: "Use sorted sets"
   278→                    id: sortedSetsOutcome
   279→            no:
   280→                value: "No"
   281→                nextQuestion: extraInfo
   282→    extraInfo:
   283→        text: |
   284→            Do you need to store extra information for each key AND you don't need
   285→            set operations (union, intersection, difference)?
   286→        whyAsk: |
   287→            Hashes allow you to associate data with each key, but they don't support
   288→            set operations. If you need both extra data and set operations, sets are not suitable
   289→        answers:
   290→            yes:
   291→                value: "Yes"
   292→                outcome:
   293→                    label: "Use hashes"
   294→                    id: hashesOutcome
   295→            no:
   296→                value: "No"
   297→                nextQuestion: integerIndices
   298→    integerIndices:
   299→        text: |
   300→            Are the keys always simple integer indices in a known range?
   301→        whyAsk: |
   302→            String bitmaps provide minimum memory overhead and efficient random access
   303→            for integer indices, with bitwise operations equivalent to set operations
   304→        answers:
   305→            yes:
   306→                value: "Yes"
   307→                outcome:
   308→                    label: "Use strings (bitmaps)"
   309→                    id: stringsOutcome
   310→            no:
   311→                value: "No"
   312→                outcome:
   313→                    label: "Use sets"
   314→                    id: setsOutcome
   315→```
   316→
   317→### Sequences
   318→
   319→You would normally store sequences of string or binary data using sorted sets,
   320→lists, or streams. They each have advantages and disadvantages for particular purposes.  
   321→Use the decision tree below as a guide to choosing the best data type for your task.
   322→
   323→```decision-tree {id="sequences-tree"}
   324→id: sequences-tree
   325→scope: sequences
   326→rootQuestion: root
   327→questions:
   328→    root:
   329→        text: |
   330→            Do you need to maintain an arbitrary priority order, lexicographical order,
   331→            frequently access elements by index, or perform set operations?
   332→        whyAsk: |
   333→            Sorted sets are the only sequence type that supports both ordering and set operations.
   334→            While lists also support indexing, it is O(n) for lists but O(log n) for sorted sets,
   335→            so sorted sets are more efficient if you need frequent index access
   336→        answers:
   337→            yes:
   338→                value: "Yes"
   339→                outcome:
   340→                    label: "Use sorted sets"
   341→                    id: sortedSetsOutcome
   342→            no:
   343→                value: "No"
   344→                nextQuestion: timestampOrder
   345→    timestampOrder:
   346→        text: |
   347→            Do you need to store and retrieve elements primarily in timestamp order
   348→            or manage multiple consumers reading from the sequence?
   349→        whyAsk: |
   350→            Streams are the only sequence type that supports timestamp-based ordering
   351→            and consumer groups for managing multiple readers with at-least-once delivery
   352→        answers:
   353→            yes:
   354→                value: "Yes"
   355→                outcome:
   356→                    label: "Use streams"
   357→                    id: streamsOutcome
   358→            no:
   359→                value: "No"
   360→                outcome:
   361→                    label: "Use lists"
   362→                    id: listsOutcome
   363→```

[TextBlock(text="Based on the available documentation in the knowledge base, I can provide you with information about using Redis Streams for message queuing, though the KB doesn't have a comprehensive Streams tutorial. Here's what I found:

## Redis Streams for Message Queuing

Redis Streams are designed for append-only log data, time series, and message queuing scenarios. They store sequences of entries, each with field-value pairs, and include built-in support for **consumer groups** to manage multiple readers with at-least-once delivery.

### Key Characteristics

**Structure**: Sequence of entries, each with a set of field-value pairs
**Operations**: add, read, trim
**Best for**: Log data, time series, message queues, and append-only structures

### When to Use Streams vs Other Data Types

Use Streams when you need:
- Timestamp-based ordering of messages
- Multiple consumers reading from the same sequence
- Consumer groups for managing multiple readers
- At-least-once delivery guarantees

If you don't need consumer groups or timestamp ordering, Lists might be simpler for basic queue operations.

### Basic Commands

While the KB doesn't have detailed command documentation, the main Streams commands are:

- **XADD**: Add entries to a stream
- **XREAD**: Read entries from a stream
- **XREADGROUP**: Read entries as part of a consumer group
- **XGROUP**: Manage consumer groups

### Idempotent Message Processing (Redis 8.6+)

Redis 8.6 introduced idempotent message processing to prevent duplicate entries when producers retry:

```redis
XADD mystream IDMP producer-1 iid-1 * field value      # Manual producer/iid
XADD mystream IDMPAUTO producer-2 * field value        # Auto-generated iid
```

This ensures at-most-once production even when network issues or crashes cause retries.

### Multi-Key Considerations

In clustered environments, XREAD and XREADGROUP are **single-slot** operations - all stream keys must hash to the same slot. Use hash tags to ensure this:

```redis
XREAD STREAMS {app}:stream1 {app}:stream2 0-0 0-0
```

[来源: compare-data-types.md > Data type features > Streams]
[来源: multi-key-operations.md > Read-only commands]
[来源: idempotency.md > Idempotency modes]

---

**Note**: The knowledge base doesn't contain the main Redis Streams tutorial with detailed examples of consumer groups, acknowledgments, and pending entries. For comprehensive documentation, you may need to refer to the official Redis documentation at redis.io/docs/latest/develop/data-types/streams/.")]

Based on the available documentation in the knowledge base, I can provide you with information about using Redis Streams for message queuing, though the KB doesn't have a comprehensive Streams tutorial. Here's what I found:

## Redis Streams for Message Queuing

Redis Streams are designed for append-only log data, time series, and message queuing scenarios. They store sequences of entries, each with field-value pairs, and include built-in support for **consumer groups** to manage multiple readers with at-least-once delivery.

### Key Characteristics

**Structure**: Sequence of entries, each with a set of field-value pairs
**Operations**: add, read, trim
**Best for**: Log data, time series, message queues, and append-only structures

### When to Use Streams vs Other Data Types

Use Streams when you need:
- Timestamp-based ordering of messages
- Multiple consumers reading from the same sequence
- Consumer groups for managing multiple readers
- At-least-once delivery guarantees

If you don't need consumer groups or timestamp ordering, Lists might be simpler for basic queue operations.

### Basic Commands

While the KB doesn't have detailed command documentation, the main Streams commands are:

- **XADD**: Add entries to a stream
- **XREAD**: Read entries from a stream
- **XREADGROUP**: Read entries as part of a consumer group
- **XGROUP**: Manage consumer groups

### Idempotent Message Processing (Redis 8.6+)

Redis 8.6 introduced idempotent message processing to prevent duplicate entries when producers retry:

```redis
XADD mystream IDMP producer-1 iid-1 * field value      # Manual producer/iid
XADD mystream IDMPAUTO producer-2 * field value        # Auto-generated iid
```

This ensures at-most-once production even when network issues or crashes cause retries.

### Multi-Key Considerations

In clustered environments, XREAD and XREADGROUP are **single-slot** operations - all stream keys must hash to the same slot. Use hash tags to ensure this:

```redis
XREAD STREAMS {app}:stream1 {app}:stream2 0-0 0-0
```

[来源: compare-data-types.md > Data type features > Streams]
[来源: multi-key-operations.md > Read-only commands]
[来源: idempotency.md > Idempotency modes]

---

**Note**: The knowledge base doesn't contain the main Redis Streams tutorial with detailed examples of consumer groups, acknowledgments, and pending entries. For comprehensive documentation, you may need to refer to the official Redis documentation at redis.io/docs/latest/develop/data-types/streams/.

query: Redis Bloom Filter 的误判率怎么配置？
answer:
Redis Bloom Filter 的误判率可以通过以下方式配置：

## 1. 创建时指定（推荐）

使用 `BF.RESERVE` 命令创建 Bloom Filter 时指定误判率：

```redis
BF.RESERVE {key} {error_rate} {capacity} [EXPANSION expansion] [NONSCALING]
```

**示例**：
```redis
BF.RESERVE bikes:models 0.001 1000000
```
- `error_rate`: 0.001 表示 0.1% 的误判率（千分之一）
- `capacity`: 1000000 表示预期容量为 100 万个元素

## 2. 误判率取值范围

- **类型**：double
- **有效范围**：`(0 .. 1)`，即 0% 到 100%
- **限制**：任何大于 0.25 的值会被视为 0.25
- **默认值**：0.01（1% 误判率）

## 3. 常见误判率与内存消耗

不同误判率对应的哈希函数数量和内存占用：

| 误判率 | 哈希函数数 | 每项所需位数 |
|--------|-----------|-------------|
| 1%     | 7         | 9.585 bits  |
| 0.1%   | 10        | 14.378 bits |
| 0.01%  | 14        | 19.170 bits |

**计算公式**：
- 哈希函数数量：`ceil(-ln(error_rate) / ln(2))`
- 每项位数：`-ln(error_rate) / ln(2)^2`

## 4. 全局默认配置（Redis 8.0+）

可以在 `redis.conf` 中设置全局默认误判率：

```conf
bf-error-rate 0.01
```

或运行时修改：
```redis
CONFIG SET bf-error-rate 0.01
```

## 注意事项

- 误判率越低，内存消耗越大
- 如果使用 `NONSCALING` 标志，达到容量后误判率会上升
- 建议根据实际场景在内存和准确性之间权衡

Though the valid range is `(0 .. 1)` (corresponding to `> 0%` to `< 100%` false positive rate), any value greater than `0.25` is treated as `0.25`.\\\\n\\\\nDefault: `0.01`\\\\n\\\\nAdded in v8.0.0.\\\\n\\\\nExpansion factor for Bloom filters.\\\\n\\\\nType: integer\\\\n\\\\nValid range: `[0 .. 32768]`.\\\\n\\\\nDefault: `2`\\\\n\\\\nInitial capacity for Bloom filters.\\\\n\\\\nType: integer\\\\n\\\\nValid range: `[1 .. 1048576]`\\\\n\\\\nDefault: `100`\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 4.6566,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"1760b768\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1760b768-004\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/bloom-filter.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Bloom filter\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Reserving Bloom filters > Total size of a Bloom filter\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"The actual memory used by a Bloom filter is a function of the chosen error rate:\\\\n\\\\nThe optimal number of hash functions is `ceil(-ln(error_rate) / ln(2))`.\\\\n\\\\nThe required number of bits per item, given the desired `error_rate` and the optimal number of hash functions, is `-ln(error_rate) / ln(2)^2`. Hence, the required number of bits in the filter is `capacity * -ln(error_rate) / ln(2)^2`.\\\\n\\\\n* **1%** error rate requires 7 hash functions and 9.585 bits per item.\\\\n* **0.1%** error rate requires 10 hash functions and 14.378 bits per item.\\\\n* **0.01%** error rate requires 14 hash functions and 19.170 bits per item.\\\\n\\\\nJust as a comparison, when using a Redis set for membership testing the memory needed is:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nmemory_with_sets = capacity*(192b + value)\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nFor a set of IP addresses, for example, we would have around 40 bytes (320 bits) per item - considerably higher than the 19.170 bits we need for a Bloom filter with a 0.01% false positives rate.\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 3.3047,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"1760b768\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1760b768-003\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/bloom-filter.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Bloom filter\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Reserving Bloom filters > 4. `NONSCALING`\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"The rate is a decimal value between 0 and 1. For example, for a desired false positive rate of 0.1% (1 in 1000), error_rate should be set to 0.001.\\\\n\\\\nThis is the number of items you expect having in your filter in total and is trivial when you have a static set but it becomes more challenging when your set grows over time. It\'s important to get the number right because if you **oversize** - you\'ll end up wasting memory. If you **undersize**, the filter will fill up and a new one will have to be stacked on top of it (sub-filter stacking). In the cases when a filter consists of multiple sub-filters stacked on top of each other latency for adds stays the same, but the latency for presence checks increases. The reason for this is the way the checks work: a regular check would first be performed on the top (latest) filter and if a negative answer is returned the next one is checked and so on. That\'s where the added latency comes from.\\\\n\\\\nAdding an item to a Bloom filter never fails due to the data structure \\\\\\"filling up\\\\\\". Instead, the error rate starts to grow. To keep the error close to the one set on filter initialization, the Bloom filter will auto-scale, meaning, when capacity is reached, an additional sub-filter will be created. \\\\n The size of the new sub-filter is the size of the last sub-filter multiplied by `EXPANSION`. If the number of items to be stored in the filter is unknown, we recommend that you use an expansion of 2 or more to reduce the number of sub-filters. Otherwise, we recommend that you use an expansion of 1 to reduce memory consumption. The default expansion value is 2. \\\\n \\\\n The filter will keep adding more hash functions for every new sub-filter in order to keep your desired error rate. \\\\n\\\\nMaybe you\'re wondering \\\\\\"Why would I create a smaller filter with a high expansion rate if I know I\'m going to scale anyway?\\\\\\"; the answer is: for cases where you need to keep many filters (let\'s say a filter per user, or per product) and most of them will stay small, but some with more activity will have to scale.\\\\n\\\\nIf you know you\'re not going to scale use the `NONSCALING` flag because that way the filter will use one hash function less. Just remember that if you ever do reach the initially assigned capacity - your error rate will start to grow.\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 2.7903,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"1760b768\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1760b768-002\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/bloom-filter.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Bloom filter\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Reserving Bloom filters\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"Consider a bike manufacturer that makes a million different kinds of bikes and you\'d like to avoid using a duplicate model name in new models. A Bloom filter can be used to detect duplicates. In the example that follows, you\'ll create a filter with space for a million entries and with a 0.1% error rate. Add one model name and check if it exists. Then add multiple model names and check if they exist.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> BF.RESERVE bikes:models 0.001 1000000\\\\nOK\\\\n> BF.ADD bikes:models \\\\\\"Smoky Mountain Striker\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> BF.EXISTS bikes:models \\\\\\"Smoky Mountain Striker\\\\\\"\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> BF.MADD bikes:models \\\\\\"Rocky Mountain Racer\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Cloudy City Cruiser\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Windy City Wippet\\\\\\"\\\\n1) (integer) 1\\\\n2) (integer) 1\\\\n3) (integer) 1\\\\n> BF.MEXISTS bikes:models \\\\\\"Rocky Mountain Racer\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Cloudy City Cruiser\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Windy City Wippet\\\\\\"\\\\n1) (integer) 1\\\\n2) (integer) 1\\\\n3) (integer) 1\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nNote: there is always a chance that even with just a few items, there could be a false positive, meaning an item could \\\\\\"exist\\\\\\" even though it has not been explicitly added to the Bloom filter. For a more in depth understanding of the probabilistic nature of a Bloom filter, check out the blog posts linked at the bottom of this page.\\\\n\\\\nWith the Redis Bloom filter, most of the sizing work is done for you: \\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nBF.RESERVE {key} {error_rate} {capacity} [EXPANSION expansion] [NONSCALING]\\\\n```\\"\\n },\\n {\\n \\"score\\": 1.1392,\\n \\"doc_id\\": \\"0065cf20\\",\\n \\"chunk_id\\": \\"0065cf20-000\\",\\n \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/configuration.md\\",\\n \\"title\\": \\"Configuration Parameters\\",\\n \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis probabilistic data structure configuration parameters\\",\\n \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n \\"text\\": \\"As of Redis 8 in Redis Open Source (Redis 8), configuration parameters for the probabilistic data structures are now set in the following ways:\\\\n* At load time via your `redis.conf` file.\\\\n* At run time (where applicable) using the [`CONFIG SET`]() command.\\\\n\\\\nAlso, Redis 8 persists probabilistic configuration parameters just like any other configuration parameters (e.g., using the [`CONFIG REWRITE`]() command).\\\\n\\\\nThe following table summarizes which Bloom filter configuration parameters can be set at run-time, and compatibility with Redis Software and Redis Cloud.\\\\n\\\\n| Parameter name

[TextBlock(text='Redis Bloom Filter 的误判率可以通过以下方式配置：

## 1. 创建时指定（推荐）

使用 `BF.RESERVE` 命令创建 Bloom Filter 时指定误判率：

```redis
BF.RESERVE {key} {error_rate} {capacity} [EXPANSION expansion] [NONSCALING]
```

**示例**：
```redis
BF.RESERVE bikes:models 0.001 1000000
```
- `error_rate`: 0.001 表示 0.1% 的误判率（千分之一）
- `capacity`: 1000000 表示预期容量为 100 万个元素

## 2. 误判率取值范围

- **类型**：double
- **有效范围**：`(0 .. 1)`，即 0% 到 100%
- **限制**：任何大于 0.25 的值会被视为 0.25
- **默认值**：0.01（1% 误判率）

## 3. 常见误判率与内存消耗

不同误判率对应的哈希函数数量和内存占用：

| 误判率 | 哈希函数数 | 每项所需位数 |
|--------|-----------|-------------|
| 1%     | 7         | 9.585 bits  |
| 0.1%   | 10        | 14.378 bits |
| 0.01%  | 14        | 19.170 bits |

**计算公式**：
- 哈希函数数量：`ceil(-ln(error_rate) / ln(2))`
- 每项位数：`-ln(error_rate) / ln(2)^2`

## 4. 全局默认配置（Redis 8.0+）

可以在 `redis.conf` 中设置全局默认误判率：

```conf
bf-error-rate 0.01
```

或运行时修改：
```redis
CONFIG SET bf-error-rate 0.01
```

## 注意事项

- 误判率越低，内存消耗越大
- 如果使用 `NONSCALING` 标志，达到容量后误判率会上升
- 建议根据实际场景在内存和准确性之间权衡

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/bloom-filter.md > Reserving Bloom filters]  
[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/configuration.md > Default parameters for Bloom filters]')]

query: When should I use Redis Hashes vs JSON?
answer:
Based on the Redis documentation, here's when to use Hashes vs JSON:

## Use **JSON** when:
- You need **nested data structures** (fields and arrays) or geospatial indexing with Redis query engine
- You need to **access sub-values efficiently** without transmitting the entire object over the network
- You need **atomic partial updates** (incrementing values, adding/removing array elements, appending strings)
- You need **indexing and querying** capabilities for complex document structures

## Use **Hashes** when:
- You need indexing/querying with Redis query engine but **don't need nested structures**
- You need **lower memory overhead and faster field access** than JSON
- You need to set **expiration times on individual fields** within the document
- You need frequent access to individual fields with **string or binary data values**
- Your data structure is flat (no deep nesting)

## Use **Strings** when:
- You have simple data with **bit fields or integer indices**
- You don't need frequent field-level access
- You want the **most compact and efficient** storage

## Key Trade-offs:
- **Memory & Processing**: JSON > Hashes > Strings (highest to lowest)
- **Functionality**: JSON supports deep nesting and complex queries; Hashes support flat structures with field-level operations
- **Performance**: Hashes offer faster field access than JSON for flat structures

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/compare-data-types.md > Choose a data type > Documents]

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/json/use_cases.md]

Hashes support general field access, but strings are more compact and efficient if you don\'t need it\\\\n        answers:\\\\n            yes:\\\\n                value: \\\\\\"Yes\\\\\\"\\\\n outcome:\\\\n                    label: \\\\\\"Use strings\\\\\\"\\\\n                    id: stringOutcome\\\\n```\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.2032,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"4d4f701e\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"4d4f701e-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/json/use_cases.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Use cases\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"You can of course use Redis native data structures to store JSON objects, and that\'s a common practice. For example, you can serialize JSON and save it in a Redis String.\\\\n\\\\nHowever, Redis JSON provides several benefits over this approach.\\\\n\\\\n**Access and retrieval of subvalues**\\\\n\\\\nWith JSON, you can get nested values without having to transmit the entire object over the network. Being able to access sub-objects can lead to greater efficiencies when you\'re storing large JSON objects in Redis.\\\\n\\\\n**Atomic partial updates**\\\\n\\\\nJSON allows you to atomically run operations like incrementing a value, adding, or removing elements from an array, append strings, and so on. To do the same with a serialized object, you have to retrieve and then reserialize the entire object, which can be expensive and also lack atomicity.\\\\n\\\\n**Indexing and querying**\\\\n\\\\nWhen you store JSON objects as Redis strings, there\'s no good way to query those objects. On the other hand, storing these objects as JSON using Redis Open Source lets you index and query them. This capability is provided by the Redis Query Engine.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

- You need **nested data structures** (fields and arrays) or geospatial indexing with Redis query engine
- You need to **access sub-values efficiently** without transmitting the entire object over the network
- You need **atomic partial updates** (incrementing values, adding/removing array elements, appending strings)
- You need **indexing and querying** capabilities for complex document structures

## Use **Hashes** when:
- You need indexing/querying with Redis query engine but **don't need nested structures**
- You need **lower memory overhead and faster field access** than JSON
- You need to set **expiration times on individual fields** within the document
- You need frequent access to individual fields with **string or binary data values**
- Your data structure is flat (no deep nesting)

## Use **Strings** when:
- You have simple data with **bit fields or integer indices**
- You don't need frequent field-level access
- You want the **most compact and efficient** storage

## Key Trade-offs:
- **Memory & Processing**: JSON > Hashes > Strings (highest to lowest)
- **Functionality**: JSON supports deep nesting and complex queries; Hashes support flat structures with field-level operations
- **Performance**: Hashes offer faster field access than JSON for flat structures

query: How does HyperLogLog count unique elements in Redis?
answer:
HyperLogLog in Redis is a probabilistic data structure that estimates the cardinality (count of unique elements) of a set using a clever algorithm that trades perfect accuracy for extremely efficient memory usage.

## How it works

**Core principle**: Instead of storing actual elements (which would require memory proportional to the number of items), HyperLogLog maintains only a mathematical "state" that allows it to estimate uniqueness. This means:

- **Constant memory**: Uses up to 12 KB maximum, regardless of how many unique elements you're counting
- **Standard error**: 0.81% - very accurate for an approximation
- **Massive scale**: Can estimate cardinality of sets with up to 2^64 members

## Key operations

```redis
# Add elements to count
PFADD bikes Hyperion Deimos Phobes Quaoar
# Returns: (integer) 1

# Get estimated count of unique elements
PFCOUNT bikes
# Returns: (integer) 4

# Merge multiple HyperLogLogs
PFADD commuter_bikes Salacia Mimas Quaoar
PFMERGE all_bikes bikes commuter_bikes
PFCOUNT all_bikes
# Returns: (integer) 6  (Quaoar was in both, counted once)
```

## Why use it instead of Sets?

While you could use `SADD` to add elements to a Set and `SCARD` to count them, HyperLogLog is vastly more memory-efficient when counting millions or billions of unique items. The tradeoff is you get an approximation (±0.81%) instead of an exact count, and you can't retrieve the actual elements.

## Performance

- `PFADD` and `PFCOUNT`: O(1) constant time and space
- `PFMERGE`: O(n) where n is the number of HyperLogLogs being merged

**[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/hyperloglogs.md > Use cases]**

query: Redis Lists 作为消息队列和 Streams 有什么区别？
answer:
根据检索到的 Redis 官方文档，我来对比 Redis Lists 和 Streams 作为消息队列的区别：

## 核心区别

### 1. 数据结构设计

**Lists（链表）**：
- 简单的字符串值链表
- 设计用于栈和队列的基本操作
- 通过 `LPUSH`/`RPUSH` 添加，`LPOP`/`RPOP` 移除

**Streams（流）**：
- 每个条目包含多个字段-值对的序列
- 专为日志数据、时间序列等仅追加结构优化
- 每个条目自动生成唯一 ID（时间戳+序列号）

### 2. 消息消费模式

**Lists**：
- **简单的生产者-消费者模式**：生产者 `LPUSH`，消费者 `RPOP`
- **阻塞操作**：`BRPOP`/`BLPOP` 避免轮询，等待新元素到达
- **消息一旦被 POP 就永久删除**，无法重新消费
- 多个消费者竞争同一消息（先到先得）

**Streams**：
- **内置 Consumer Groups（消费者组）支持**
- **消息确认机制**：消费者需要显式确认（ACK）消息处理完成
- **至少一次交付保证**：未确认的消息可以重新分配给其他消费者
- **支持多个消费者组独立消费同一流**

### 3. 消息持久性与重放

**Lists**：
- 消息被消费后立即删除，**无法重新读取历史消息**
- 适合一次性处理的任务队列

**Streams**：
- 消息持久化在流中，**可以从任意位置读取**（包括历史消息）
- 支持按 ID 范围查询、从最后一条消息开始读取（`XREAD` 使用 `+`）
- 可以设置保留策略（如按时间或数量裁剪）

### 4. 可靠性保证

**Lists**：
- 如果消费者在处理消息时崩溃，消息丢失
- 可以用 `LMOVE`/`BLMOVE` 实现更安全的队列（原子移动到备份列表）

**Streams**：
- **Pending Entries List（待处理列表）**：跟踪已分配但未确认的消息
- 消费者崩溃后，其他消费者可以接管未完成的消息
- 支持消息重试和死信队列模式

### 5. 适用场景

**Lists 适合**：
- 简单的后台任务队列（如 Sidekiq、Resque）
- 不需要消息持久化和重放
- 单一消费者或竞争消费模式
- 对可靠性要求不高的场景

**Streams 适合**：
- 需要消息持久化和历史回溯
- 多消费者协作处理（消费者组）
- 需要消息确认和故障恢复
- 日志收集、事件溯源、时间序列数据

## 总结

Redis Lists 是轻量级的队列实现，适合简单场景；Streams 是功能完整的消息流系统，提供消费者组、消息确认、持久化等企业级特性。**如果需要可靠的消息队列，官方推荐使用 Streams 而非 Lists。**

---

**来源**：
- [Redis Lists 文档](file:///home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md) > Common use cases for lists, Blocking operations on lists
- [Compare data types](file:///home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/compare-data-types.md) > Streams

This is better for time series use cases, because they are typically interested in the data during a given time window, rather than a fixed number of samples.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.5967,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"43b5f91b\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"43b5f91b-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis lists\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Basic commands\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis lists are linked lists of string values.\\\\nRedis lists are frequently used to:\\\\n\\\\n* Implement stacks and queues.\\\\n* Build queue management for background worker systems.\\\\n\\\\n* [`LPUSH`]() adds a new element to the head of a list; [`RPUSH`]() adds to the tail.\\\\n* [`LPOP`]() removes and returns an element from the head of a list; [`RPOP`]() does the same but from the tails of a list. \\\\n* [`LLEN`]() returns the length of a list.\\\\n* [`LMOVE`]() atomically moves elements from one list to another.\\\\n* [`LRANGE`]() extracts a range of elements from a list.\\\\n* [`LTRIM`]() reduces a list to the specified range of elements.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

new commands: `XDELEX` and `XACKDEL`; extension to `XADD` and `XTRIM`.\\\\n- Bitmap - `BITOP`: new operators: `DIFF`, `DIFF1`, `ANDOR`, and `ONE`.\\\\n- Query Engine - new SVS-VAMANA vector index type which supports vector compression.\\\\n- More than 15 performance and resource utilization improvements.\\\\n- New metrics: per-slot usage metrics, key size distributions for basic data types, and more.\\\\n\\\\n- Alpine and Debian Docker images - https://hub.docker.com/_/redis\\\\n- Install using snap - see https://github.com/redis/redis-snap\\\\n- Install using brew - see https://github.com/redis/homebrew-redis\\\\n- Install using RPM - see https://github.com/redis/redis-rpm\\\\n- Install using Debian APT - see https://github.com/redis/redis-debian\\\\n\\\\n- Ubuntu 22.04 (Jammy Jellyfish), 24.04 (Noble Numbat)\\\\n- Rocky Linux 8.10, 9.5\\\\n- AlmaLinux 8.10, 9.5\\\\n- Debian 12 (Bookworm)\\\\n- macOS 13 (Ventura), 14 (Sonoma), 15 (Sequoia)\\\\n\\\\n- (CVE-2025-32023) Fix out-of-bounds write in `HyperLogLog` commands.\\\\n- (CVE-2025-48367) Retry accepting other connections even if the accepted connection reports an error.\\\\n\\\\n- [#14141](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14141) Keyspace notifications - new event types:\\\\n  - `OVERWRITTEN` - the value of a key is completely overwritten\\\\n  - `TYPE_CHANGED` - key type change\\\\n\\\\n- [#14162](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14162) Crash when using evport with I/O threads.\\\\n- [#14163](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14163) `EVAL` crash when error table is empty.\\\\n- [#14144](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14144) Vector sets - RDB format is not compatible with big endian machines.\\\\n- [#14165](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14165) Endless client blocking for blocking commands.\\\\n- [#14164](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14164) Prevent `CLIENT UNBLOCK` from unblocking `CLIENT PAUSE`.\\\\n- [#14216](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14216) TTL was not removed by the `SET` command.\\\\n- [#14224](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14224) `HINCRBYFLOAT` removes field expiration on replica.\\\\n\\\\n- [#Q6430](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/6430) More compression variants for the SVS-VAMANA vector index.\\\\n- [#Q6535](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/6535) `SHARD_K_RATIO` parameter - favor network latency over accuracy for KNN vector query in a Redis cluster (unstable feature) (MOD-10359).\\\\n- [#14144](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14144) Vector set - improve RDB loading / RESTORE speed by storing the worst link info .\\\\n\\\\n- [#14051](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14051) `RedisModule_Get*`, `RedisModule_Set*` - allow modules to access Redis configurations.\\\\n- [#14114](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14114) `RM_UnsubscribeFromKeyspaceEvents` - unregister a module from specific keyspace notifications.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.854,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"40893428\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"40893428-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-7.4-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisstack 7.4 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Community Edition 7.4.0-v0 (July 2024) > Headlines\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"**Data Structures**\\\\n\\\\n`Hash`: Redis now supports expiration of individual hash fields. Redis already supports key expiration. For each key, users can specify a time when it should expire, or specify the remaining time-to-live (TTL) after which it would expire. One very frequent request was to allow specifying expiration time or TTL also for individual hash fields, which is now supported using nine new Redis commands:\\\\n- `HEXPIRE`, `HPEXPIRE`, `HEXPIREAT`, `HPEXPIREAT` - set the time when specific hash fields should expire, or the remaining time-to-live for specific fields. \\\\n- `HTTL`, `HPTTL`, `HEXPIRETIME`, `HPEXPIRETIME` - retrieve the time when specific hash fields should expire, or the remaining time-to-live for specific fields\\\\n- `HPERSIST` - remove the expiration of specific hash fields.\\\\n\\\\n`Streams`: It is now possible to start reading from the last stream message using `XREAD` with the new id value `+`.\\\\nThere are many additional improvements, including new command arguments, security, performance, and resource utilization enhancements, several new metrics and configuration parameters were introduced, and multiple bugs were fixed.\\\\n\\\\n`Time series`: The latest time series data structure adds a highly requested feature: insertion-filter for close samples. Many sensors report data periodically. Often, the difference between the measured value and the previously measured value is negligible and related to random noise or to measurement accuracy limitations. When both the time difference and the value difference between the current and the previous sample are small, it may be preferable to ignore (not to add) the new measurement.\\\\n\\\\n`JSON`: Introduces a fix to avoid duplicating AOF commands multiple times in `JSON.MSET`.\\\\n\\\\n`Probabilistic`: Now, an error is returned if `CMS.MERGE` results in an overflow or underflow.\\\\n\\\\n**Search and query**\\\\n\\\\n- New `BFLOAT16` and `FLOAT16` vector data types reduce memory consumed by vectors while preserving accuracy.\\\\n- Support for indexing empty and missing values and enhanced developer experience for queries with exact matching capabilities.\\\\n- Developers can now match `TAG` fields without needing to escape special characters, making the onboarding process and use of the query syntax simpler.\\\\n- Geospatial search capabilities have been expanded with new `INTERSECT` and `DISJOINT` operators, and ergonomics have been improved by providing better reporting of the memory consumed by the index and exposing the Full-text scoring in the aggregation pipeline.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nIf one or more fields of a hash key expire after a query begins (using FT.SEARCH or FT.AGGREGATE), Redis does not account for these lazily expired fields. As a result, keys with expired fields may still be included in the query results, leading to potentially incorrect or inconsistent results.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Removal of triggers and functions**\\\\n\\\\nRedis Stack 7.4 will no longer include triggers and functions. To ensure a seamless upgrade, remove any T&F functions created before loading an RDB file into the new Redis Stack.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.5446,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"39de5f37\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"39de5f37-013\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisce/redisos-8.2-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisos 8.2 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Open Source 8.2-RC1 (July 2025) > Metrics\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis 8.2 introduces major performance and memory footprint improvements, new commands, and command extensions.\\\\n\\\\nRedis 8.2-RC1 is available as a Docker image and can be downloaded from [Docker Hub](https://hub.docker.com/_/redis). Additional distributions will be introduced in upcoming pre-releases.\\\\n\\\\n- (CVE-2025-27151) redis-check-aof may lead to stack overflow and potential RCE\\\\n\\\\n- [#14130](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14130) Streams - new commands: `XDELEX` and `XACKDEL`; extension to `XADD` and `XTRIM`.\\\\n- [#14039](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14039) New command: `CLUSTER SLOT-STATS` - get per-slot usage metrics such as key count, CPU time, and network I/O.\\\\n- [#14122](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14122) `VSIM` - new `IN` operator for filtering expressions.\\\\n- [#Q6329](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/6329), [#Q6394](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/6394) - Query Engine - new SVS-VAMANA vector index type which supports vector compression (optimized for Intel machines).\\\\n\\\\n- [#14143](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14143) Gracefully handle short read errors for hashes with TTL during full sync.\\\\n\\\\n- [#14103](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14103) Optimize `BITCOUNT` by introducing prefetching.\\\\n- [#14121](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14121) Optimize `SCAN` by performing expiration checks only on DBs with volatile keys.\\\\n- [#14140](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14140) Optimize expiry check in `scanCallback`.\\\\n- [#14131](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14131) Optimize `LREM`, `LPOS`, `LINSERT`, `ZRANK`, and more by caching `string2ll` results in `quicklistCompare`.\\\\n- [#14088](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14088) Optimize `COPY`, `RENAME`, and `RESTORE` when TTL is used.\\\\n- [#14074](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14074) Reduce the overhead associated with tracking `malloc`’s usable memory.\\\\n- [#13900](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/13900) Optimize the client’s cron to avoid blocking the main thread.\\\\n- [#J1350](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/pull/1350) JSON - memory footprint improvement by inlining numbers (MOD-9511).\\\\n\\\\n- [#14067](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/14067) `INFO`: `used_memory_peak_time` - time when `used_memory_peak` was hit.\\\\n- [#13990](https://github.com/redis/redis/pull/13990) `INFO`:\\\\n  - `master_current_sync_attempts` - number of times the replica attempted to sync to a master since last disconnection.\\\\n  - `master_total_sync_attempts` - number of times the replica attempted to sync to a master.\\\\n  - `master_link_up_since_seconds` - number of seconds since the link has been up.\\\\n  - `total_disconnect_time_sec` - total cumulative time the replica has been disconnected.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_MXSJo5CxvhPYjtvQC7vguI', content='     1→---
     2→categories:
     3→- docs

    13→description: 'Introduction to Redis lists
    14→
    15→  '
    16→id: 43b5f91b
    17→ingested_at: '2026-02-14T15:01:27Z'
    18→linkTitle: Lists
    19→source_commit: a9ff1a3
    20→source_path: content/develop/data-types/lists.md
    21→source_repo: https://github.com/redis/docs
    22→title: Redis lists
    23→weight: 20
    24→---
    25→
    26→Redis lists are linked lists of string values.
    27→Redis lists are frequently used to:
    28→
    29→* Implement stacks and queues.
    30→* Build queue management for background worker systems.
    31→
    32→## Basic commands
    33→
    34→* [`LPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/lpush" >}}) adds a new element to the head of a list; [`RPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/rpush" >}}) adds to the tail.
    35→* [`LPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/lpop" >}}) removes and returns an element from the head of a list; [`RPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/rpop" >}}) does the same but from the tails of a list. 
    36→* [`LLEN`]({{< relref "/commands/llen" >}}) returns the length of a list.
    37→* [`LMOVE`]({{< relref "/commands/lmove" >}}) atomically moves elements from one list to another.
    38→* [`LRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/lrange" >}}) extracts a range of elements from a list.
    39→* [`LTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/ltrim" >}}) reduces a list to the specified range of elements.
    40→
    41→### Blocking commands
    42→
    43→Lists support several blocking commands.
    44→For example:
    45→
    46→* [`BLPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/blpop" >}}) removes and returns an element from the head of a list.
    47→  If the list is empty, the command blocks until an element becomes available or until the specified timeout is reached.
    48→* [`BLMOVE`]({{< relref "/commands/blmove" >}}) atomically moves elements from a source list to a target list.
    49→  If the source list is empty, the command will block until a new element becomes available.
    50→
    51→See the [complete series of list commands]({{< relref "/commands/" >}}?group=list).
    52→
    53→## Examples
    54→
    55→* Treat a list like a queue (first in, first out):
    56→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="queue" description="Queue pattern: Use LPUSH to add items and RPOP to remove them in FIFO order when you need to process items in the order they were added" buildsUpon="lpush_rpush, lpop_rpop" >}}
    57→> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1
    58→(integer) 1
    59→> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:2
    60→(integer) 2
    61→> RPOP bikes:repairs
    62→"bike:1"
    63→> RPOP bikes:repairs
    64→"bike:2"
    65→{{< /clients-example >}}
    66→
    67→* Treat a list like a stack (first in, last out):
    68→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="stack" description="Stack pattern: Use LPUSH to add items and LPOP to remove them in LIFO order when you need to process items in reverse order" buildsUpon="lpush_rpush" >}}
    69→> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1
    70→(integer) 1
    71→> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:2
    72→(integer) 2
    73→> LPOP bikes:repairs
    74→"bike:2"
    75→> LPOP bikes:repairs
    76→"bike:1"
    77→{{< /clients-example >}}
    78→
    79→* Check the length of a list:
    80→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="llen" description="Foundational: Get the number of elements in a list using LLEN to check list size" >}}
    81→> LLEN bikes:repairs
    82→(integer) 0
    83→{{< /clients-example >}}
    84→
    85→* Atomically pop an element from one list and push to another:
    86→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="lmove_lrange" description="Atomic transfer: Use LMOVE to move elements between lists in a single operation when you need to transfer items without race conditions" difficulty="intermediate" buildsUpon="lpush_rpush, lpop_rpop" >}}
    87→> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1
    88→(integer) 1
    89→> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:2
    90→(integer) 2
    91→> LMOVE bikes:repairs bikes:finished LEFT LEFT
    92→"bike:2"
    93→> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1
    94→1) "bike:1"
    95→> LRANGE bikes:finished 0 -1
    96→1) "bike:2"
    97→{{< /clients-example >}}
    98→
    99→* To limit the length of a list you can call [`LTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/ltrim" >}}):
   100→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="ltrim.1" description="Capped lists: Use LTRIM to keep only a specific range of elements when you need to maintain a fixed-size list" difficulty="intermediate" buildsUpon="lpush_rpush" >}}
   101→> DEL bikes:repairs
   102→(integer) 1
   103→> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5
   104→(integer) 5
   105→> LTRIM bikes:repairs 0 2
   106→OK
   107→> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1
   108→1) "bike:1"
   109→2) "bike:2"
   110→3) "bike:3"
   111→{{< /clients-example >}}
   112→
   113→### What are Lists?
   114→
   115→To explain the List data type it's better to start with a little bit of theory,
   116→as the term *List* is often used in an improper way by information technology
   117→folks. For instance "Python Lists" are not what the name may suggest (Linked
   118→Lists), but rather Arrays (the same data type is called Array in
   119→Ruby actually).
   120→
   121→From a very general point of view a List is just a sequence of ordered
   122→elements: 10,20,1,2,3 is a list. But the properties of a List implemented using
   123→an Array are very different from the properties of a List implemented using a
   124→*Linked List*.
   125→
   126→Redis lists are implemented via Linked Lists. This means that even if you have
   127→millions of elements inside a list, the operation of adding a new element in
   128→the head or in the tail of the list is performed *in constant time*. The speed of adding a
   129→new element with the [`LPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/lpush" >}}) command to the head of a list with ten
   130→elements is the same as adding an element to the head of list with 10
   131→million elements.
   132→
   133→What's the downside? Accessing an element *by index* is very fast in lists
   134→implemented with an Array (constant time indexed access) and not so fast in
   135→lists implemented by linked lists (where the operation requires an amount of
   136→work proportional to the index of the accessed element).
   137→
   138→Redis Lists are implemented with linked lists because for a database system it
   139→is crucial to be able to add elements to a very long list in a very fast way.
   140→Another strong advantage, as you'll see in a moment, is that Redis Lists can be
   141→taken at constant length in constant time.
   142→
   143→When fast access to the middle of a large collection of elements is important,
   144→there is a different data structure that can be used, called sorted sets.
   145→Sorted sets are covered in the [Sorted sets]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/sorted-sets" >}}) tutorial page.
   146→
   147→### First steps with Redis Lists
   148→
   149→The [`LPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/lpush" >}}) command adds a new element into a list, on the
   150→left (at the head), while the [`RPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/rpush" >}}) command adds a new
   151→element into a list, on the right (at the tail). Finally the
   152→[`LRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/lrange" >}}) command extracts ranges of elements from lists:
   153→
   154→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="lpush_rpush" description="Foundational: Add elements to both ends of a list using LPUSH (left/head) and RPUSH (right/tail) to build ordered sequences" >}}
   155→> DEL bikes:repairs
   156→(integer) 1
   157→> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1
   158→(integer) 1
   159→> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:2
   160→(integer) 2
   161→> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:important_bike
   162→(integer) 3
   163→> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1
   164→1) "bike:important_bike"
   165→2) "bike:1"
   166→3) "bike:2"
   167→{{< /clients-example >}}
   168→
   169→Note that [`LRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/lrange" >}}) takes two indexes, the first and the last
   170→element of the range to return. Both the indexes can be negative, telling Redis
   171→to start counting from the end: so -1 is the last element, -2 is the
   172→penultimate element of the list, and so forth.
   173→
   174→As you can see [`RPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/rpush" >}}) appended the elements on the right of the list, while
   175→the final [`LPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/lpush" >}}) appended the element on the left.
   176→
   177→Both commands are *variadic commands*, meaning that you are free to push
   178→multiple elements into a list in a single call:
   179→
   180→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="variadic" description="Variadic operations: Add multiple elements in a single command using LPUSH or RPUSH when you need to reduce round trips to the server" buildsUpon="lpush_rpush" >}}
   181→> DEL bikes:repairs
   182→(integer) 1
   183→> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3
   184→(integer) 3
   185→> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:important_bike bike:very_important_bike
   186→> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1
   187→1) "bike:very_important_bike"
   188→2) "bike:important_bike"
   189→3) "bike:1"
   190→4) "bike:2"
   191→5) "bike:3"
   192→{{< /clients-example >}}
   193→
   194→An important operation defined on Redis lists is the ability to *pop elements*.
   195→Popping elements is the operation of both retrieving the element from the list,
   196→and eliminating it from the list, at the same time. You can pop elements
   197→from left and right, similarly to how you can push elements in both sides
   198→of the list. We'll add three elements and pop three elements, so at the end of this
   199→sequence of commands the list is empty and there are no more elements to
   200→pop:
   201→
   202→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="lpop_rpop" description="Foundational: Remove and retrieve elements from both ends of a list using LPOP (left/head) and RPOP (right/tail) to consume items" >}}
   203→> DEL bikes:repairs
   204→(integer) 1
   205→> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3
   206→(integer) 3
   207→> RPOP bikes:repairs
   208→"bike:3"
   209→> LPOP bikes:repairs
   210→"bike:1"
   211→> RPOP bikes:repairs
   212→"bike:2"
   213→> RPOP bikes:repairs
   214→(nil)
   215→{{< /clients-example >}}
   216→
   217→Redis returned a NULL value to signal that there are no elements in the
   218→list.
   219→
   220→### Common use cases for lists
   221→
   222→Lists are useful for a number of tasks, two very representative use cases
   223→are the following:
   224→
   225→* Remember the latest updates posted by users into a social network.
   226→* Communication between processes, using a consumer-producer pattern where the producer pushes items into a list, and a consumer (usually a *worker*) consumes those items and executes actions. Redis has special list commands to make this use case both more reliable and efficient.
   227→
   228→For example both the popular Ruby libraries [resque](https://github.com/resque/resque) and
   229→[sidekiq](https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq) use Redis lists under the hood in order to
   230→implement background jobs.
   231→
   232→The popular Twitter social network [takes the latest tweets](http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Real-Time-Delivery-Twitter)
   233→posted by users into Redis lists.
   234→
   235→To describe a common use case step by step, imagine your home page shows the latest
   236→photos published in a photo sharing social network and you want to speedup access.
   237→
   238→* Every time a user posts a new photo, we add its ID into a list with [`LPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/lpush" >}}).
   239→* When users visit the home page, we use `LRANGE 0 9` in order to get the latest 10 posted items.
   240→
   241→### Capped lists
   242→
   243→In many use cases we just want to use lists to store the *latest items*,
   244→whatever they are: social network updates, logs, or anything else.
   245→
   246→Redis allows us to use lists as a capped collection, only remembering the latest
   247→N items and discarding all the oldest items using the [`LTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/ltrim" >}}) command.
   248→
   249→The [`LTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/ltrim" >}}) command is similar to [`LRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/lrange" >}}), but **instead of displaying the
   250→specified range of elements** it sets this range as the new list value. All
   251→the elements outside the given range are removed.
   252→
   253→For example, if you're adding bikes on the end of a list of repairs, but only
   254→want to worry about the 3 that have been on the list the longest:
   255→
   256→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="ltrim" description="Capped lists: Use LTRIM with positive indexes to keep a range of elements from the beginning when you need to maintain a fixed-size list" difficulty="intermediate" buildsUpon="lpush_rpush" >}}
   257→> DEL bikes:repairs
   258→(integer) 1
   259→> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5
   260→(integer) 5
   261→> LTRIM bikes:repairs 0 2
   262→OK
   263→> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1
   264→1) "bike:1"
   265→2) "bike:2"
   266→3) "bike:3"
   267→{{< /clients-example >}}
   268→
   269→The above [`LTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/ltrim" >}}) command tells Redis to keep just list elements from index
   270→0 to 2, everything else will be discarded. This allows for a very simple but
   271→useful pattern: doing a List push operation + a List trim operation together 
   272→to add a new element and discard elements exceeding a limit. Using 
   273→[`LTRIM`]({{< relref "/commands/ltrim" >}}) with negative indexes can then be used to keep only the 3 most recently added:
   274→
   275→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="ltrim_end_of_list" description="Capped lists with negative indexes: Use LTRIM with negative indexes to keep the most recent elements when you need to maintain a fixed-size list of latest items" difficulty="intermediate" buildsUpon="lpush_rpush" >}}
   276→> DEL bikes:repairs
   277→(integer) 1
   278→> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5
   279→(integer) 5
   280→> LTRIM bikes:repairs -3 -1
   281→OK
   282→> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1
   283→1) "bike:3"
   284→2) "bike:4"
   285→3) "bike:5"
   286→{{< /clients-example >}}
   287→
   288→The above combination adds new elements and keeps only the 3
   289→newest elements into the list. With [`LRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/lrange" >}}) you can access the top items
   290→without any need to remember very old data.
   291→
   292→Note: while [`LRANGE`]({{< relref "/commands/lrange" >}}) is technically an O(N) command, accessing small ranges
   293→towards the head or the tail of the list is a constant time operation.
   294→
   295→## Blocking operations on lists
   296→
   297→Lists have a special feature that make them suitable to implement queues,
   298→and in general as a building block for inter process communication systems:
   299→blocking operations.
   300→
   301→Imagine you want to push items into a list with one process, and use
   302→a different process in order to actually do some kind of work with those
   303→items. This is the usual producer / consumer setup, and can be implemented
   304→in the following simple way:
   305→
   306→* To push items into the list, producers call [`LPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/lpush" >}}).
   307→* To extract / process items from the list, consumers call [`RPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/rpop" >}}).
   308→
   309→However it is possible that sometimes the list is empty and there is nothing
   310→to process, so [`RPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/rpop" >}}) just returns NULL. In this case a consumer is forced to wait
   311→some time and retry again with [`RPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/rpop" >}}). This is called *polling*, and is not
   312→a good idea in this context because it has several drawbacks:
   313→
   314→1. Forces Redis and clients to process useless commands (all the requests when the list is empty will get no actual work done, they'll just return NULL).
   315→2. Adds a delay to the processing of items, since after a worker receives a NULL, it waits some time. To make the delay smaller, we could wait less between calls to [`RPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/rpop" >}}), with the effect of amplifying problem number 1, i.e. more useless calls to Redis.
   316→
   317→So Redis implements commands called [`BRPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/brpop" >}}) and [`BLPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/blpop" >}}) which are versions
   318→of [`RPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/rpop" >}}) and [`LPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/lpop" >}}) able to block if the list is empty: they'll return to
   319→the caller only when a new element is added to the list, or when a user-specified
   320→timeout is reached.
   321→
   322→This is an example of a [`BRPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/brpop" >}}) call we could use in the worker:
   323→
   324→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="brpop" description="Blocking operations: Use BRPOP to wait for elements with a timeout when you need to implement producer-consumer patterns without polling" difficulty="intermediate" buildsUpon="lpush_rpush, lpop_rpop" >}}
   325→> DEL bikes:repairs
   326→(integer) 1
   327→> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2
   328→(integer) 2
   329→> BRPOP bikes:repairs 1
   330→1) "bikes:repairs"
   331→2) "bike:2"
   332→> BRPOP bikes:repairs 1
   333→1) "bikes:repairs"
   334→2) "bike:1"
   335→> BRPOP bikes:repairs 1
   336→(nil)
   337→(2.01s)
   338→{{< /clients-example >}}
   339→
   340→It means: "wait for elements in the list `bikes:repairs`, but return if after 1 second
   341→no element is available".
   342→
   343→Note that you can use 0 as timeout to wait for elements forever, and you can
   344→also specify multiple lists and not just one, in order to wait on multiple
   345→lists at the same time, and get notified when the first list receives an
   346→element.
   347→
   348→A few things to note about [`BRPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/brpop" >}}):
   349→
   350→1. Clients are served in an ordered way: the first client that blocked waiting for a list, is served first when an element is pushed by some other client, and so forth.
   351→2. The return value is different compared to [`RPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/rpop" >}}): it is a two-element array since it also includes the name of the key, because [`BRPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/brpop" >}}) and [`BLPOP`]({{< relref "/commands/blpop" >}}) are able to block waiting for elements from multiple lists.
   352→3. If the timeout is reached, NULL is returned.
   353→
   354→There are more things you should know about lists and blocking ops. We
   355→suggest that you read more on the following:
   356→
   357→* It is possible to build safer queues or rotating queues using [`LMOVE`]({{< relref "/commands/lmove" >}}).
   358→* There is also a blocking variant of the command, called [`BLMOVE`]({{< relref "/commands/blmove" >}}).
   359→
   360→## Automatic creation and removal of keys
   361→
   362→So far in our examples we never had to create empty lists before pushing
   363→elements, or removing empty lists when they no longer have elements inside.
   364→It is Redis' responsibility to delete keys when lists are left empty, or to create
   365→an empty list if the key does not exist and we are trying to add elements
   366→to it, for example, with [`LPUSH`]({{< relref "/commands/lpush" >}}).
   367→
   368→This is not specific to lists, it applies to all the Redis data types
   369→composed of multiple elements -- Streams, Sets, Sorted Sets and Hashes.
   370→
   371→Basically we can summarize the behavior with three rules:
   372→
   373→1. When we add an element to an aggregate data type, if the target key does not exist, an empty aggregate data type is created before adding the element.
   374→2. When we remove elements from an aggregate data type, if the value remains empty, the key is automatically destroyed. The Stream data type is the only exception to this rule.
   375→3. Calling a read-only command such as [`LLEN`]({{< relref "/commands/llen" >}}) (which returns the length of the list), or a write command removing elements, with an empty key, always produces the same result as if the key is holding an empty aggregate type of the type the command expects to find.
   376→
   377→Examples of rule 1:
   378→
   379→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="rule_1" description="Automatic creation: Redis automatically creates a list when you push to a non-existent key, simplifying initialization" >}}
   380→> DEL new_bikes
   381→(integer) 0
   382→> LPUSH new_bikes bike:1 bike:2 bike:3
   383→(integer) 3
   384→{{< /clients-example >}}
   385→
   386→However we can't perform operations against the wrong type if the key exists:
   387→
   388→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="rule_1.1" description="Type safety: Redis prevents operations on wrong data types, returning WRONGTYPE error when you try to use list commands on non-list keys" buildsUpon="rule_1" >}}
   389→> DEL new_bikes
   390→(integer) 1
   391→> SET new_bikes bike:1
   392→OK
   393→> TYPE new_bikes
   394→string
   395→> LPUSH new_bikes bike:2 bike:3
   396→(error) WRONGTYPE Operation against a key holding the wrong kind of value
   397→{{< /clients-example >}}
   398→
   399→Example of rule 2:
   400→
   401→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="rule_2" description="Automatic removal: Redis automatically deletes empty lists, freeing memory when the last element is removed" buildsUpon="lpush_rpush, lpop_rpop" >}}
   402→> DEL bikes:repairs
   403→(integer) 1
   404→> LPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3
   405→(integer) 3
   406→> EXISTS bikes:repairs
   407→(integer) 1
   408→> LPOP bikes:repairs
   409→"bike:3"
   410→> LPOP bikes:repairs
   411→"bike:2"
   412→> LPOP bikes:repairs
   413→"bike:1"
   414→> EXISTS bikes:repairs
   415→(integer) 0
   416→{{< /clients-example >}}
   417→
   418→The key no longer exists after all the elements are popped.
   419→
   420→Example of rule 3:
   421→
   422→{{< clients-example set="list_tutorial" step="rule_3" description="Nil handling: Read-only commands on non-existent keys return empty results (0 or nil) instead of errors, treating them as empty lists" >}}
   423→> DEL bikes:repairs
   424→(integer) 0
   425→> LLEN bikes:repairs
   426→(integer) 0
   427→> LPOP bikes:repairs
   428→(nil)
   429→{{< /clients-example >}}
   430→
   431→
   432→## Limits
   433→
   434→The maximum length of a Redis list is 2^32 - 1 (4,294,967,295) elements.
   435→
   436→## Performance
   437→
   438→List operations that access its head or tail are O(1), which means they're highly efficient.
   439→However, commands that manipulate elements within a list are usually O(n).
   440→Examples of these include [`LINDEX`]({{< relref "/commands/lindex" >}}), [`LINSERT`]({{< relref "/commands/linsert" >}}), and [`LSET`]({{< relref "/commands/lset" >}}).
   441→Exercise caution when running these commands, mainly when operating on large lists.
   442→
   443→## Alternatives
   444→
   445→Consider [Redis streams]({{< relref "/develop/data-types/streams" >}}) as an alternative to lists when you need to store and process an indeterminate series of events.
   446→
   447→## Learn more
   448→
   449→* [Redis Lists Explained](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PB5SeOkkxQc) is a short, comprehensive video explainer on Redis lists.
   450→* [Redis University's RU101](https://university.redis.com/courses/ru101/) covers Redis lists in detail.

</system-reminder>

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_aSKIoIGnV9kAkn9yjAIRLt', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.8448,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"0a0527f7\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"0a0527f7-033\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-7.2-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisstack 7.2 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Stack 7.2.0-v0 (August 2023) > Headlines:\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis server 7.2 introduces significant memory and speed optimizations for lists, sets, and sorted sets, several improvements, including encoding improvements for sets and lists, stream consumer group improvements, and improved durability.\\\\nSearch and Query brings the frequently asked Geo polygons queries for basic shapes and improved query performance on sorting in different scenarios. \\\\nJSON introduces two new commands: [JSON.MERGE](https://redis.io/commands/json.merge/) and [JSON.MSET](https://redis.io/commands/json.mset/) for more efficient data manipulation.\\\\nPreview of triggers and functions that allows developers to run JavaScript functions inside the Redis process.\\\\nLastly, 7.2 adds the option to use the new protocol [RESP3](https://github.com/redis/redis-specifications/blob/master/protocol/RESP3.md) improving the response format for all commands.\\\\n\\\\n**Redis server**:\\\\nRedis server 7.2 brings performance and resource utilization improvements, including significant memory and speed optimizations for lists, sets, and sorted sets. This new version adds a new `WITHSCORE` command argument for [ZRANK](https://redis.io/commands/zrank/) and [ZREVRANK](https://redis.io/commands/zrevrank/), new commands, such as [CLIENT NO-TOUCH](https://redis.io/commands/client-no-touch/) for clients to run commands without affecting LRU/LFU of keys, and more. Redis 7.2 brings behavior changes by introducing a new format (version 11) for RDB files, which is incompatible with older versions, changing module API, and other changes.\\\\n\\\\n**Search and Query**:\\\\nThis new major version introduces the frequently asked [Geo Polygon](https://redis.io/commands/ft.search/#examples) Search. Adding the [GEOSHAPE](https://redis.io/commands/ft.create/) field type that supports polygon shapes using the [WKT notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Well-known_text_representation_of_geometry). In addition to the existing `GEO` for geo range queries, now an alias for `GEOPOINT`, we add `GEOSHAPE` with the support for `POLYGON` and `POINT` as new shapes formats and polygons operations.\\\\n\\\\nIn addition, 7.2 brings improvements in performance for `SORT BY` operations using [`FT.SEARCH`](https://redis.io/commands/ft.search/#optional-arguments) and [`FT.AGGREGATE`](https://redis.io/commands/ft.aggregate/#optional-arguments), and the new `FORMAT` for better readability and future support for better error handling responses on `FT.SEARCH` and `FT.AGGREGATE` in RESP3 only.\\\\n\\\\n**JSON**:\\\\nJSON introduces two new commands:\\\\n - [JSON.MERGE](https://redis.io/commands/json.merge/) merges a given JSON value into matching paths so that the JSON values at the matching paths are updated, deleted, or expanded.\\\\n - [JSON.MSET](https://redis.io/commands/json.mset/) sets or updates one or more JSON values according to specified key-path-value triplets.\\\\n\\\\n**Graph**:\\\\n\\\\nGraph capabilities are no longer included in Redis Stack. See the [RedisGraph End-of-Life Announcement](https://redis.com/blog/redisgraph-eol/).\\\\n\\\\n> [!WARNING]  \\\\nIf you are using graph capabilities with an older version of Redis Stack - please don\'t upgrade.\\\\n\\\\n**Triggers and functions preview**:\\\\nTriggers and functions is part of Redis Stack 7.2 as public preview, any feedback is highly appreciated.\\\\n\\\\nTriggers and functions provides support for running JavaScript functions inside the Redis process. These functions can be executed on-demand, by an event-driven trigger, or by a stream processing trigger. Triggers and functions empowers developers to build and maintain real-time applications by moving logic closer to the data, ensuring a lower latency whilst delivering the best developer experience.\\\\n\\\\nTry it out with the [triggers and functions quick start](https://redis.io/docs/interact/programmability/triggers-and-functions/quick_start/).\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]
