[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_Df2VcPLDT10JB9Nae5eDnf', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.9977,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"40893428\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"40893428-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-7.4-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisstack 7.4 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Community Edition 7.4.0-v0 (July 2024) > Headlines\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"**Data Structures**\\\\n\\\\n`Hash`: Redis now supports expiration of individual hash fields. Redis already supports key expiration. For each key, users can specify a time when it should expire, or specify the remaining time-to-live (TTL) after which it would expire. One very frequent request was to allow specifying expiration time or TTL also for individual hash fields, which is now supported using nine new Redis commands:\\\\n- `HEXPIRE`, `HPEXPIRE`, `HEXPIREAT`, `HPEXPIREAT` - set the time when specific hash fields should expire, or the remaining time-to-live for specific fields. \\\\n- `HTTL`, `HPTTL`, `HEXPIRETIME`, `HPEXPIRETIME` - retrieve the time when specific hash fields should expire, or the remaining time-to-live for specific fields\\\\n- `HPERSIST` - remove the expiration of specific hash fields.\\\\n\\\\n`Streams`: It is now possible to start reading from the last stream message using `XREAD` with the new id value `+`.\\\\nThere are many additional improvements, including new command arguments, security, performance, and resource utilization enhancements, several new metrics and configuration parameters were introduced, and multiple bugs were fixed.\\\\n\\\\n`Time series`: The latest time series data structure adds a highly requested feature: insertion-filter for close samples. Many sensors report data periodically. Often, the difference between the measured value and the previously measured value is negligible and related to random noise or to measurement accuracy limitations. When both the time difference and the value difference between the current and the previous sample are small, it may be preferable to ignore (not to add) the new measurement.\\\\n\\\\n`JSON`: Introduces a fix to avoid duplicating AOF commands multiple times in `JSON.MSET`.\\\\n\\\\n`Probabilistic`: Now, an error is returned if `CMS.MERGE` results in an overflow or underflow.\\\\n\\\\n**Search and query**\\\\n\\\\n- New `BFLOAT16` and `FLOAT16` vector data types reduce memory consumed by vectors while preserving accuracy.\\\\n- Support for indexing empty and missing values and enhanced developer experience for queries with exact matching capabilities.\\\\n- Developers can now match `TAG` fields without needing to escape special characters, making the onboarding process and use of the query syntax simpler.\\\\n- Geospatial search capabilities have been expanded with new `INTERSECT` and `DISJOINT` operators, and ergonomics have been improved by providing better reporting of the memory consumed by the index and exposing the Full-text scoring in the aggregation pipeline.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nIf one or more fields of a hash key expire after a query begins (using FT.SEARCH or FT.AGGREGATE), Redis does not account for these lazily expired fields. As a result, keys with expired fields may still be included in the query results, leading to potentially incorrect or inconsistent results.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Removal of triggers and functions**\\\\n\\\\nRedis Stack 7.4 will no longer include triggers and functions. To ensure a seamless upgrade, remove any T&F functions created before loading an RDB file into the new Redis Stack.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.7256,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"8d8f4284\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"8d8f4284-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/compare-data-types.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Compare data types\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Data type features > Streams\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"-   **Structure**: sequence of entries, each with a set of field-value pairs.\\\\n-   **Operations**: add, read, trim.\\\\n-   **Suitable for**: Log data, time series, and other append-only structures.\\\\n\\\\nStreams store sequences of entries, each with a set of field-value pairs.\\\\nThey are optimized for appending new entries and reading them in order,\\\\nand so they are useful for implementing log data, time series, and other\\\\nappend-only data structures. They also have built-in support for consumer groups\\\\nto manage multiple readers and ensure at-least-once delivery.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.838,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"4103dc5c\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"4103dc5c-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/deprecated-features/triggers-and-functions/concepts/triggers/Stream_Triggers.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Stream triggers\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Register a stream consumer\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Triggers and functions provide an API that allows to register a stream trigger. Do not get confused with [Redis streams consumer groups](), triggers and functions uses the Redis Module API to efficiently read the stream and manage its consumers. This approach gives a much better performance as there is no need to invoke any Redis commands in order to read from the stream. Lets see a simple example:\\\\n\\\\n```js\\\\n#!js api_version=1.0 name=myFirstLibrary\\\\n\\\\nredis.registerStreamTrigger(\\\\n    \\\\\\"consumer\\\\\\", // consumer name\\\\n    \\\\\\"stream\\\\\\", // streams prefix\\\\n    function(c, data) {\\\\n        // callback to run on each element added to the stream\\\\n        redis.log(JSON.stringify(data, (key, value) =>\\\\n            typeof value === \'bigint\'\\\\n                ? value.toString()\\\\n                : value // return everything else unchanged\\\\n        ));\\\\n    }\\\\n);\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nArgument Description:\\\\n\\\\n* consumer - the consumer name.\\\\n* stream - streams name prefix on which to trigger the callback.\\\\n* callback - the callback to invoke on each element in the stream. Following the same rules of [sync and async invocation](). The callback will be invoke only on primary shard.\\\\n\\\\nIf we register this library (see the [quick start]() section to learn how to Register a RedisGears function) and run the following command on our Redis:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nXADD stream:1 * foo1 bar1\\\\nXADD stream:1 * foo2 bar2\\\\nXADD stream:2 * foo1 bar1\\\\nXADD stream:2 * foo2 bar2\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe will see the following line on the Redis log file:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n2630021:M 05 Jul 2022 17:13:22.506 * <redisgears_2> {\\\\\\"id\\\\\\":[\\\\\\"1657030402506\\\\\\",\\\\\\"0\\\\\\"],\\\\\\"stream_name\\\\\\":\\\\\\"stream:1\\\\\\",\\\\\\"record\\\\\\":[[\\\\\\"foo1\\\\\\",\\\\\\"bar1\\\\\\"]]}\\\\n2630021:M 05 Jul 2022 17:13:25.323 * <redisgears_2> {\\\\\\"id\\\\\\":[\\\\\\"1657030405323\\\\\\",\\\\\\"0\\\\\\"],\\\\\\"stream_name\\\\\\":\\\\\\"stream:1\\\\\\",\\\\\\"record\\\\\\":[[\\\\\\"foo2\\\\\\",\\\\\\"bar2\\\\\\"]]}\\\\n2630021:M 05 Jul 2022 17:13:29.475 * <redisgears_2> {\\\\\\"id\\\\\\":[\\\\\\"1657030409475\\\\\\",\\\\\\"0\\\\\\"],\\\\\\"stream_name\\\\\\":\\\\\\"stream:2\\\\\\",\\\\\\"record\\\\\\":[[\\\\\\"foo1\\\\\\",\\\\\\"bar1\\\\\\"]]}\\\\n2630021:M 05 Jul 2022 17:13:32.715 * <redisgears_2> {\\\\\\"id\\\\\\":[\\\\\\"1657030412715\\\\\\",\\\\\\"0\\\\\\"],\\\\\\"stream_name\\\\\\":\\\\\\"stream:2\\\\\\",\\\\\\"record\\\\\\":[[\\\\\\"foo2\\\\\\",\\\\\\"bar2\\\\\\"]]}\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThe `data` argument which pass to the stream consumer callback are in the following format:\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\n{\\\\n    \\\\\\"id\\\\\\": [\\\\\\"<ms>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<seq>\\\\\\"],\\\\n    \\\\\\"stream_name\\\\\\": \\\\\\"<stream name>\\\\\\",\\\\n    \\\\\\"stream_name_raw\\\\\\": \\\\\\"<stream name as ArrayBuffer>\\\\\\",\\\\n    \\\\\\"record\\\\\\":[\\\\n        [\\\\\\"<key>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<value>\\\\\\"],\\\\n        .\\\\n        .\\\\n        [\\\\\\"<key>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<value>\\\\\\"]\\\\n    ],\\\\n    \\\\\\"record_raw\\\\\\":[\\\\n        [\\\\\\"<key_raw>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<value_raw>\\\\\\"],\\\\n        .\\\\n        .\\\\n        [\\\\\\"<key_raw>\\\\\\", \\\\\\"<value_raw>\\\\\\"]\\\\n    ],\\\\n}\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThe reason why the record is a list of touples and not an object is because the Redis Stream specifications allows duplicate keys.\\\\n\\\\nNotice that `stream_name` and `record` fields might contains `null`\'s if the data can not be decoded as string. the `*_raw` fields will always be provided and will contains the data as `JS` `ArrayBuffer`.\\\\n\\\\nWe can observe the streams which are tracked by our registered [TextBlock(text='根据检索到的 Redis 官方文档，我来对比 Redis Lists 和 Streams 作为消息队列的区别：

## 核心区别

### 1. 数据结构设计

**Lists（链表）**：
- 简单的字符串值链表
- 设计用于栈和队列的基本操作
- 通过 `LPUSH`/`RPUSH` 添加，`LPOP`/`RPOP` 移除

**Streams（流）**：
- 每个条目包含多个字段-值对的序列
- 专为日志数据、时间序列等仅追加结构优化
- 每个条目自动生成唯一 ID（时间戳+序列号）

### 2. 消息消费模式

**Lists**：
- **简单的生产者-消费者模式**：生产者 `LPUSH`，消费者 `RPOP`
- **阻塞操作**：`BRPOP`/`BLPOP` 避免轮询，等待新元素到达
- **消息一旦被 POP 就永久删除**，无法重新消费
- 多个消费者竞争同一消息（先到先得）

**Streams**：
- **内置 Consumer Groups（消费者组）支持**
- **消息确认机制**：消费者需要显式确认（ACK）消息处理完成
- **至少一次交付保证**：未确认的消息可以重新分配给其他消费者
- **支持多个消费者组独立消费同一流**

### 3. 消息持久性与重放

**Lists**：
- 消息被消费后立即删除，**无法重新读取历史消息**
- 适合一次性处理的任务队列

**Streams**：
- 消息持久化在流中，**可以从任意位置读取**（包括历史消息）
- 支持按 ID 范围查询、从最后一条消息开始读取（`XREAD` 使用 `+`）
- 可以设置保留策略（如按时间或数量裁剪）

### 4. 可靠性保证

**Lists**：
- 如果消费者在处理消息时崩溃，消息丢失
- 可以用 `LMOVE`/`BLMOVE` 实现更安全的队列（原子移动到备份列表）

**Streams**：
- **Pending Entries List（待处理列表）**：跟踪已分配但未确认的消息
- 消费者崩溃后，其他消费者可以接管未完成的消息
- 支持消息重试和死信队列模式

### 5. 适用场景

**Lists 适合**：
- 简单的后台任务队列（如 Sidekiq、Resque）
- 不需要消息持久化和重放
- 单一消费者或竞争消费模式
- 对可靠性要求不高的场景

**Streams 适合**：
- 需要消息持久化和历史回溯
- 多消费者协作处理（消费者组）
- 需要消息确认和故障恢复
- 日志收集、事件溯源、时间序列数据

## 总结

Redis Lists 是轻量级的队列实现，适合简单场景；Streams 是功能完整的消息流系统，提供消费者组、消息确认、持久化等企业级特性。**如果需要可靠的消息队列，官方推荐使用 Streams 而非 Lists。**

---

**来源**：
- [Redis Lists 文档](file:///home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md) > Common use cases for lists, Blocking operations on lists
- [Compare data types](file:///home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/compare-data-types.md) > Streams')]

query: What are Redis Bitfields and when would I use them?
answer:
Based on the search results, here's what Redis Bitfields are and when to use them:

## What are Redis Bitfields?

Redis Bitfields let you **set, increment, and get integer values of arbitrary bit length** within binary-encoded Redis strings. You can operate on anything from unsigned 1-bit integers to signed 63-bit integers, all stored efficiently in a compact binary format.

## Key Features

- **Atomic operations**: Support atomic read, write, and increment operations
- **Flexible bit widths**: Handle integers from 1-bit to 63-bit
- **Multiple operations**: Can perform multiple bitfield operations in a single command
- **Efficient storage**: Uses binary-encoded strings for compact memory usage

## When to Use Them

Bitfields are ideal for **managing counters and numerical values**, especially when you need:

1. **Multiple related counters per key** - Store several metrics together efficiently
2. **Atomic updates** - Ensure thread-safe counter operations
3. **Space efficiency** - Pack multiple values into a single Redis key

## Practical Example

Here's a real-world scenario from the documentation - tracking bicycle statistics (price and number of owners):

```redis
# Set initial price to 1000 at offset 0
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats SET u32 #0 1000
1) (integer) 0

# Decrease price by 50, increment owner count
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 -50 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 950
2) (integer) 1

# Increase price by 500, increment owner count again
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 500 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2

# Read both values
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats GET u32 #0 GET u32 #1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2
```

## Available Commands

- `BITFIELD` - Atomically sets, increments, and reads one or more values
- `BITFIELD_RO` - Read-only variant of BITFIELD

## Performance

`BITFIELD` has O(n) complexity, where n is the number of counters accessed.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/bitfields.md > Performance]

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_EylLwRG0gsbZWjYQS6uuWa', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 3.7087,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"1a0bd081\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1a0bd081-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/bitfields.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis bitfields\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Performance\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis bitfields let you set, increment, and get integer values of arbitrary bit length.\\\\nFor example, you can operate on anything from unsigned 1-bit integers to signed 63-bit integers.\\\\n\\\\nThese values are stored using binary-encoded Redis strings.\\\\nBitfields support atomic read, write and increment operations, making them a good choice for managing counters and similar numerical values.\\\\n\\\\n* [`BITFIELD`]() atomically sets, increments and reads one or more values.\\\\n* [`BITFIELD_RO`]() is a read-only variant of [`BITFIELD`]().\\\\n\\\\nSuppose you want to maintain two metrics for various bicycles: the current price and the number of owners over time. You can represent these counters with a 32-bit wide bitfield for each bike.\\\\n\\\\n* Bike 1 initially costs 1,000 (counter in offset 0) and has never had an owner. After being sold, it\'s now considered used and the price instantly drops to reflect its new condition, and it now has an owner (offset 1). After quite some time, the bike becomes a classic. The original owner sells it for a profit, so the price goes up and the number of owners does as well.Finally, you can look at the bike\'s current price and number of owners.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> BITFIELD bike:1:stats SET u32 #0 1000\\\\n1) (integer) 0\\\\n> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 -50 INCRBY u32 #1 1\\\\n1) (integer) 950\\\\n2) (integer) 1\\\\n> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 500 INCRBY u32 #1 1\\\\n1) (integer) 1450\\\\n2) (integer) 2\\\\n> BITFIELD bike:1:stats GET u32 #0 GET u32 #1\\\\n1) (integer) 1450\\\\n2) (integer) 2\\\\n\\\\n[`BITFIELD`]() is O(n), where _n_ is the number of counters accessed.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.5235,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"8d8f4284\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"8d8f4284-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/compare-data-types.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Compare data types\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Data type features\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis provides a wide range of data types to store your data.\\\\nThe following are highly specialized for precise purposes:\\\\n\\\\n-   [Geospatial]():\\\\n    store strings with associated coordinates for geospatial queries.\\\\n-   [Vector sets]():\\\\n    store strings with associated vector data (and optional metadata)\\\\n    for vector similarity queries.\\\\n-   [Probabilistic data types]():\\\\n    keep approximate counts and other statistics for large datasets.\\\\n-   [Time series]():\\\\n    store real-valued data points along with the time they were collected.\\\\n\\\\nThe remaining data types are more general-purpose:\\\\n\\\\n-   [Strings]():\\\\n    store text or binary data.\\\\n-   [Hashes]():\\\\n    store key-value pairs within a single key.\\\\n-   [JSON]():\\\\n    store structured, hierarchical arrays and key-value objects that match\\\\n    the popular [JSON](https://www.json.org/json-en.html) text file format.\\\\n-   [Lists]():\\\\n    store a simple sequence of strings.\\\\n-   [Sets]():\\\\n    store a collection of unique strings.\\\\n-   [Sorted sets]():\\\\n    store a collection of unique strings with associated scores.\\\\n-   [Streams]():\\\\n    store a sequence of entries, each with a set of field-value pairs.\\\\n\\\\nThe general-purpose data types have some overlap among their features\\\\nand indeed, you could probably emulate any of them using just strings\\\\nand a little creativity. However, each data type provides different\\\\ntradeoffs in terms of performance, memory usage, and functionality.\\\\nThis guide helps you choose the best data type for your task.\\\\n\\\\nThe sections below summarize the features of each data type.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.9707,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"1a112c0f\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"1a112c0f-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/get-started/faq.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis FAQ\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Why does Redis keep its entire dataset in memory?\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"* Redis has a different evolution path in the key-value DBs where values can contain more complex data types, with atomic operations defined on those data types. Redis data types are closely related to fundamental data structures and are exposed to the programmer as such, without additional abstraction layers.\\\\n* Redis is an in-memory but persistent on disk database, so it represents a different trade off where very high write and read speed is achieved with the limitation of data sets that can\'t be larger than memory. Another advantage of\\\\nin-memory databases is that the memory representation of complex data structures\\\\nis much simpler to manipulate compared to the same data structures on disk, so\\\\nRedis can do a lot with little internal complexity. At the same time the\\\\ntwo on-disk storage formats (RDB and AOF) don\'t need to be suitable for random\\\\naccess, so they are compact and always generated in an append-only fashion\\\\n(Even the AOF log rotation is an append-only operation, since the new version\\\\nis generated from the copy of data in memory). However this design also involves\\\\ndifferent challenges compared to traditional on-disk stores. Being the main data\\\\nrepresentation on memory, Redis operations must be carefully handled to make sure\\\\nthere is always an updated version of the data set on disk.\\\\n\\\\nTo give you a few examples (all obtained using 64-bit instances):\\\\n\\\\n* An empty instance uses ~ 3MB of memory.\\\\n* 1 Million small Keys -> String Value pairs use ~ 85MB of memory.\\\\n* 1 Million Keys -> Hash value, representing an object with 5 fields, use ~ 160 MB of memory.\\\\n\\\\nTesting your use case is trivial. Use the `redis-benchmark` utility to generate random data sets then check the space used with the `INFO memory` command.\\\\n\\\\n64-bit systems will use considerably more memory than 32-bit systems to store the same keys, especially if the keys and values are small. This is because pointers take 8 bytes in 64-bit systems. But of course the advantage is that you can\\\\nhave a lot of memory in 64-bit systems, so in order to run large Redis servers a 64-bit system is more or less required. The alternative is sharding.\\\\n\\\\nIn the past the Redis developers experimented with Virtual Memory and other systems in order to allow larger than RAM datasets, but after all we are very happy if we can do one thing well: data served from memory, disk used for storage. So for now there are no plans to create an on disk backend for Redis. Most of what\\\\nRedis is, after all, a direct result of its current design.\\\\n\\\\nIf your real problem is not the total RAM needed, but the fact that you need\\\\nto split your data set into multiple Redis instances, please read the\\\\n[partitioning page]() in this documentation for more info.\\\\n\\\\nRedis Ltd., the company sponsoring Redis development, has developed a\\\\n\\\\\\"Redis on Flash\\\\\\" solution that uses a mixed RAM/flash approach for\\\\nlarger data sets with a biased access pattern. You may check their offering\\\\nfor more information, however this feature is not part of the Redis Open Source\\\\ncode base.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.7991,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"09b2bae2\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"09b2bae2-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/bitmaps.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis bitmaps\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Example\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Bitmaps are not an actual data type, but a set of bit-oriented operations\\\\ndefined on the String type which is treated like a bit vector.\\\\nSince strings are binary safe blobs and their maximum length is 512 MB,\\\\nthey are suitable to set up to 2^32 different bits.\\\\n\\\\nYou can perform bitwise operations on one or more strings.\\\\nSome examples of bitmap use cases include:\\\\n\\\\n* Efficient set representations for cases where the members of a set correspond to the integers 0-N.\\\\n* Object permissions, where each bit represents a particular permission, similar to the way that file systems store permissions.\\\\n\\\\n* [`SETBIT`]() sets a bit at the provided offset to 0 or 1.\\\\n* [`GETBIT`]() returns the value of a bit at a given offset.\\\\n\\\\nSee the [complete list of bitmap commands](?group=bitmap).\\\\n\\\\nSuppose you have 1000 cyclists racing through the country-side, with sensors on their bikes labeled 0-999.\\\\nYou want to quickly determine whether a given sensor has pinged a tracking server within the hour to check in on a rider. \\\\n\\\\nYou can represent this scenario using a bitmap whose key references the current hour.\\\\n\\\\n* Rider 123 pings the server on January 1, 2024 within the 00:00 hour. You can then confirm that rider 123 pinged the server. You can also check to see if rider 456 has pinged the server for that same hour.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> SETBIT pings:2024-01-01-00:00 123 1\\\\n(integer) 0\\\\n> GETBIT pings:2024-01-01-00:00 123\\\\n1\\\\n> GETBIT pings:2024-01-01-00:00 456\\\\n0\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.4726,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a9efc34c\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a9efc34c-023\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/programmability/lua-api.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis Lua API reference\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Runtime libraries > _cjson_ library {#cjson-library} > `cjson.decode(x)` {#cjson.decode()}\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"This function returns a JSON-encoded string for the Lua data type provided as its argument.\\\\n\\\\nUsage example:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nredis> EVAL \\\\\\"return cjson.encode({ [\'foo\'] = \'bar\' })\\\\\\" 0\\\\n\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"foo\\\\\\\\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"bar\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"}\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThis function returns a Lua data type from the JSON-encoded string provided as its argument.\\\\n\\\\nUsage example:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nredis> EVAL \\\\\\"return cjson.decode(ARGV[1])[\'foo\']\\\\\\" 0 \'{\\\\\\"foo\\\\\\":\\\\\\"bar\\\\\\"}\'\\\\n\\\\\\"bar\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text="Based on the search results, here's what Redis Bitfields are and when to use them:

## What are Redis Bitfields?

Redis Bitfields let you **set, increment, and get integer values of arbitrary bit length** within binary-encoded Redis strings. You can operate on anything from unsigned 1-bit integers to signed 63-bit integers, all stored efficiently in a compact binary format.

## Key Features

- **Atomic operations**: Support atomic read, write, and increment operations
- **Flexible bit widths**: Handle integers from 1-bit to 63-bit
- **Multiple operations**: Can perform multiple bitfield operations in a single command
- **Efficient storage**: Uses binary-encoded strings for compact memory usage

## When to Use Them

Bitfields are ideal for **managing counters and numerical values**, especially when you need:

1. **Multiple related counters per key** - Store several metrics together efficiently
2. **Atomic updates** - Ensure thread-safe counter operations
3. **Space efficiency** - Pack multiple values into a single Redis key

## Practical Example

Here's a real-world scenario from the documentation - tracking bicycle statistics (price and number of owners):

```redis
# Set initial price to 1000 at offset 0
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats SET u32 #0 1000
1) (integer) 0

# Decrease price by 50, increment owner count
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 -50 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 950
2) (integer) 1

# Increase price by 500, increment owner count again
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats INCRBY u32 #0 500 INCRBY u32 #1 1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2

# Read both values
> BITFIELD bike:1:stats GET u32 #0 GET u32 #1
1) (integer) 1450
2) (integer) 2
```

## Available Commands

- `BITFIELD` - Atomically sets, increments, and reads one or more values
- `BITFIELD_RO` - Read-only variant of BITFIELD

## Performance

`BITFIELD` has O(n) complexity, where n is the number of counters accessed.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/bitfields.md > Performance]")]

query: How to store and query geospatial data in Redis?
answer:
Redis provides built-in geospatial data support through its **Geospatial indexes** data type. Here's how to store and query geospatial data:

## Storing Geospatial Data

Use the `GEOADD` command to add locations with their coordinates (longitude, latitude):

```redis
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.27652 37.805186 station:1
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2674626 37.8062344 station:2
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2469854 37.8104049 station:3
```

**Note:** Longitude comes before latitude with this command.

## Querying Geospatial Data

Use `GEOSEARCH` to find locations within a radius or bounding box:

```redis
GEOSEARCH bikes:rentable FROMLONLAT -122.2612767 37.7936847 BYRADIUS 5 km WITHDIST
```

This returns locations within 5km of the specified coordinates along with their distances:

```
1) 1) "station:1"
   2) "1.8523"
2) 1) "station:2"
   2) "1.4979"
3) 1) "station:3"
   2) "2.2441"
```

## Advanced: Geospatial Polygons (Redis Stack 7.2+)

For more complex shapes, Redis Stack 7.2 introduced **GEOSHAPE** field type supporting polygon queries:

- Create an index with `GEOSHAPE` field type using WKT notation
- Supports `POLYGON` and `POINT` shapes
- Query with operators like `WITHIN` and `CONTAINS`
- Works with both cartesian (X,Y) and geographic (lon, lat) coordinate systems

## Use Cases

- Finding nearby points of interest (restaurants, stores, bike stations)
- Location-based services within a radius
- Proximity searches

[Source: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/geospatial.md]

Geographic coordinate system using spherical indexing as default (`SPHERICAL`).\\\\n * [#3046](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3046) Introduce performance optimization for sorting operations on `FT.SEARCH` and `FT.AGGREGATE` as default on `DIALECT 4`. It will improve performance in 4 different scenarios, listed below:\\\\n * Skip Sorter - applied when there is no sort of any kind. The query can return once it reaches the `LIMIT` requested results.\\\\n * Partial Range - applied when there is a `SORTBY` a numeric field, with no filter or filter by the same numeric field, the query iterate on a range large enough to satisfy the `LIMIT` requested results.\\\\n * Hybrid - applied when there is a `SORTBY` a numeric field in addition to another non-numeric filter. Some results will get filtered, and the initial range may not be large enough. The iterator then is rewinded with the following ranges, and an additional iteration takes place to collect `LIMIT` requested results.\\\\n * No optimization - If there is a sort by score or by non-numeric field, there is no other option but to retrieve all results and compare their values.\\\\n * [#3651](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3651) Add `WITHCOUNT` argument that allow return accurate counts for the query results with sorting. This operation processes all results in order to get accurate count, being less performant than the optimised option (default behaviour on `DIALECT 4`).\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **JSON**:\\\\n * [#916](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/pull/916) Introduce the new `JSON.MERGE` in compliance with [RFC 7396](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7396), supporting:\\\\n * Creating new attributes on an existing JSON document\\\\n * Updating and replacing values in parent and child attributes\\\\n * Deleting existing attributes (giving `null` as value)\\\\n * Array update - replacing an entire array with the new value.\\\\n * [#944](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/pull/944) Introduce `JSON.MSET`, supporting atomic multiple sets for keys in the same hash slot.\\\\n\\\\n* **Triggers and Functions**:\\\\n * [#875](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/875) The api_version was added to the library prologue indicating the minimum required API version. Indicating the library works on the specified API version and later minor versions.\\\\n[#896](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/896) Additional optional callback on a KeySpace trigger that can perform read operations exactly when the notification happens.\\\\n * [#910](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/910) The JavaScript API is updated to be inline with JavaScript best practices. Registrations of functions and triggers is done with mandatory arguments and a single optional object.\\\\n * [#935](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/935) Ability to load an RDB from a Redis Server with the RedisGears module loaded but NOT used into a Redis Server without the RedisGears module.\\\\n * Updated commands:\\\\n * [#910](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/910) `TFUNCTION` and `TFCALL` is used instead of `RG.FUNCTION` and `RG.FCALL`.\\\\n * [#939](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/939) The commands are updated to match the Redis Functions commands. `TFCALL` combines the library and function in a single argument with \'.\' separated. Example: `TFCALL .`.\\\\n * [#900](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/900) rated the ability to run functions as a coroutine in `TFCALLASYNC`. Clients rely on `TFCALL` to never block shared connections so other commands are not delayed on such connections.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n **Improvements**\\\\n* **Search and Query**:\\\\n * [#3641](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3641) Indexing sanitizing trigger in heavily data updates scenario.\\\\n * [#3614](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3614) Several improvements in the aggregations execution pipeline.\\\\n\\\\n* **Triggers and Functions**:\\\\n * [#906](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/906) Limit the total memory usage of all combined libraries, the values can be configured during module load.\\\\n * [#940](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/940) Validate the current memory usage when uploading a new library to not exceed the max memory limit.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Changed Behavior**\\\\n* **Search and Query**:\\\\n * [#3355](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3355), [#3635](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3635) Expired keys deleted from slave\'s index, returning an empty array instead of `nil`.\\\\n\\\\n**Bug Fixes**\\\\n* **Search and Query**:\\\\n * [#3597](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3597) Duplicating alias as output name on `FT.AGGREGATE` reducer (`REDUCE` argument) isn\'t return results.\\\\n * [#3654](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3654) Added check for `@` prefix on `GROUPBY` fields returnig an error instead of wrong results.\\\\n * [#3501](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3501) Sorting by 2 or more fields follow the order not ignoring the second argument.\\\\n * [#3582](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/3582) Sorter will set lower rank in documents expired during query time, preventing clients to freeze.\\\\n\\\\n* **JSON**:\\\\n * [#1025](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/pull/1025) `JSON.TOGGLE` key space notification fix.\\\\n\\\\n* **Time series**:\\\\n * [#1471](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/RedisTimeSeries/pull/1471) Potential crash on `MRANGE` when aggregating millions of time series.\\\\n * [#1469](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/RedisTimeSeries/pull/1469) Potential memory leak in `MRANGE` after eviction.\\\\n\\\\n* **Triggers and Functions**:\\\\n * [#913](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/pull/913) Do not trigger notifications when Redis is loading from a persistence file.\\\\n\\\\n**Redis version**\\\\n* __[Redis 7.2 RC2](https://github.com/redis/redis/blob/7.2/00-RELEASENOTES)__\\\\n\\\\n**Module versions**\\\\t\\\\n* __[RediSearch 2.8.3](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/releases/tag/v2.8.3)__\\\\n* __[RedisJSON 2.6.2](https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON/releases/tag/v2.6.2)__\\\\n* __[RedisTimeSeries 1.10.1](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/RedisTimeSeries/releases/tag/v1.10.1)__\\\\n* __[RedisBloom 2.6.1](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/releases/tag/v2.6.1)__\\\\n* __[RedisGears 2.0.6](https://github.com/RedisGears/RedisGears/releases/tag/v2.0.6-m07)__\\\\n\\\\n**Recommended Client Libraries**\\\\n* Java\\\\n * [Jedis 4.4.3 or greater](https://github.com/redis/jedis/releases/tag/v4.4.3)\\\\n * [redis-om-spring 0.8.1 or greater](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-spring/releases/tag/v0.8.1)\\\\n* Python\\\\n * [redis-py 4.5.5 or greater ](https://github.com/redis/redis-py/releases/tag/v4.5.5)\\\\n * [redis-om-python 0.1.2 or greater](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-python/releases/tag/v0.1.2)\\\\n* NodeJS\\\\n * [node-redis 4.6.7 or greater](https://github.com/redis/node-redis/releases/tag/redis%404.6.7)\\\\n * [redis-om-node 0.2.0 or greater](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-node/releases/tag/v0.2.0)\\\\n* .NET\\\\n * [redis-om-dotnet 0.5.1 or greater](https://github.com/redis/redis-om-dotnet/releases/tag/v0.5.1)\\\\n * [NRedisStack 0.7.0 or greater](https://github.com/redis/NRedisStack/releases/tag/v0.7.0)\\\\n* Go\\\\n * [go-redis 9.0.4 or greater](https://github.com/redis/go-redis/releases/tag/v9.0.4)\\\\n * [rueidis 1.0.3 or greater](https://github.com/redis/rueidis/releases/tag/v1.0.3)\\\\n\\\\nCompatible with the latest [RedisInsight](https://redis.io/download). The docker image redis/redis-stack for this version is bundled with [RedisInsight 2.26](https://github.com/RedisInsight/RedisInsight/releases/tag/2.26.0).\\\\n\\\\nNote: version numbers follow the pattern:\\\\n\\\\n`x.y.z-b`\\\\n* `x.y` Redis major version\\\\n* `z` increases with even numbers as a module x.y version increases.\\\\n* `b` denotes a patch to Redis or a module (any `z` of Redis or modules). `b` will consist of a `v` + numeric value.\\"\\n }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='Redis provides built-in geospatial data support through its **Geospatial indexes** data type. Here's how to store and query geospatial data:

## Storing Geospatial Data

Use the `GEOADD` command to add locations with their coordinates (longitude, latitude):

```redis
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.27652 37.805186 station:1
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2674626 37.8062344 station:2
GEOADD bikes:rentable -122.2469854 37.8104049 station:3
```

**Note:** Longitude comes before latitude with this command.

## Querying Geospatial Data

Use `GEOSEARCH` to find locations within a radius or bounding box:

```redis
GEOSEARCH bikes:rentable FROMLONLAT -122.2612767 37.7936847 BYRADIUS 5 km WITHDIST
```

This returns locations within 5km of the specified coordinates along with their distances:

```
1) 1) "station:1"
   2) "1.8523"
2) 1) "station:2"
   2) "1.4979"
3) 1) "station:3"
   2) "2.2441"
```

## Advanced: Geospatial Polygons (Redis Stack 7.2+)

For more complex shapes, Redis Stack 7.2 introduced **GEOSHAPE** field type supporting polygon queries:

- Create an index with `GEOSHAPE` field type using WKT notation
- Supports `POLYGON` and `POINT` shapes
- Query with operators like `WITHIN` and `CONTAINS`
- Works with both cartesian (X,Y) and geographic (lon, lat) coordinate systems

## Use Cases

- Finding nearby points of interest (restaurants, stores, bike stations)
- Location-based services within a radius
- Proximity searches

[Source: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/geospatial.md]

[Additional context: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisstack/redisstack-7.2-release-notes.md > Redis Stack 7.2.0-v0 (August 2023) > Headlines]')]

## Storing Geospatial Data

## Querying Geospatial Data

Use `GEOSEARCH` to find locations within a radius or bounding box:

```redis
GEOSEARCH bikes:rentable FROMLONLAT -122.2612767 37.7936847 BYRADIUS 5 km WITHDIST
```

This returns locations within 5km of the specified coordinates along with their distances:

```
1) 1) "station:1"
```

## Advanced: Geospatial Polygons (Redis Stack 7.2+)

query: Redis TimeSeries 适合什么场景？怎么配置 retention？
answer:
## Redis TimeSeries 使用场景

Redis TimeSeries 适合以下典型场景：

### 1. 监控与运维（数据中心）
- 服务器 CPU 利用率监控
- 服务间网络延迟追踪
- 存储系统 IO 带宽分析
- 应用响应时间（如 99th percentile）分析

### 2. 环境与气象数据
- 温度、降雨量、日照时长等长期追踪
- 季节性趋势分析和预测
- 多地点数据聚合（如欧洲最低/最高温度）

### 3. IoT 传感器数据
- **飞行数据记录**：高度、航线、引擎温度、振动、压力
- **船舶日志**：风速、海况、航速、位置
- **车联网**：加速度、位置、油耗、轮胎压力、保养里程
- **智能电表**：能源消耗/生产数据

### 4. 金融交易
- 股票价格波动（毫秒级响应）
- 交易行为分析
- 异常检测（如内幕交易）

### 5. 电信服务质量
- 基站流量监控
- 负载均衡
- 峰值预测与基础设施规划

---

## Retention（数据保留）配置

### 配置优先级
1. **Key 级别**：通过 `TS.CREATE` 或 `TS.ALTER` 的 `RETENTION` 参数
2. **全局配置**：`ts-retention-policy` 参数
3. **无保留策略**（默认）

### 配置方法

**Redis 8.0 之前（启动时加载）：**
```bash
redis-server --loadmodule ./redistimeseries.so RETENTION_POLICY 25920000000
```

**Redis 8.0 及以上（运行时配置）：**
```bash
# 设置默认保留 300 天（25920000000 毫秒）
redis> CONFIG SET ts-retention-policy 25920000000

# 持久化到配置文件
redis> CONFIG REWRITE
```

**Key 级别示例：**
```bash
# 创建时指定保留 60 秒
TS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32
```

### 核心特性
- **时间窗口保留**：按毫秒指定保留时长（而非固定样本数）
- **自动过期**：超过保留期的数据自动删除
- **降采样支持**：配合 downsampling 实现长期数据压缩（支持 avg/sum/min/max/range/count/first/last）

---

**来源：**
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md]
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/configuration.md > RETENTION_POLICY]
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md]

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_sCZscKNCQppBVRC13aDctn', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 3.3456,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"7b673af6\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"7b673af6-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Use cases\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"**Monitoring (data center)**\\\\n\\\\nModern data centers have a lot of moving pieces, such as infrastructure (servers and networks) and software systems (applications and services) that need to be monitored around the clock.\\\\n\\\\nRedis Time Series allows you to plan for new resources upfront, optimize the utilization of existing resources, reconstruct the circumstances that led to outages, and identify application performance issues by analyzing and reporting on the following metrics:\\\\n\\\\n- Maximum CPU utilization per server\\\\n- Maximum network latency between two services\\\\n- Average IO bandwidth utilization of a storage system\\\\n- 99th percentile of the response time of a specific application outages\\\\n\\\\n**Weather analysis (environment)**\\\\n\\\\nRedis Time Series can be used to track environmental measurements such as the number of daily sunshine hours and hourly rainfall depth, over a period of many years. Seasonally, you can measure average rainfall depth, average daily temperature, and the maximum number of sunny hours per day, for example. Watch the increase of the maximum daily temperature over the years. Predict the expected temperature and rainfall depth in a specific location for a particular week of the year.\\\\n\\\\nMultiple time series can be collected, each for a different location. By utilizing secondary indexes, measurements can be aggregated over given geographical regions (e.g., minimal and maximal daily temperature in Europe) or over locations with specific attributes (e.g., average rainfall depth in mountainous regions).\\\\n\\\\nExample metrics include: \\\\n\\\\n- Rain (cm)\\\\n- Temperature (C)\\\\n- Sunny periods (h)\\\\n\\\\n**Analysis of the atmosphere (environment)**\\\\n\\\\nThe atmospheric concentration of CO2 is more important than ever before. Use TimeSeries to track average, maximum and minimum CO2 level per season and average yearly CO2 over the last decades. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Concentration of CO2 (ppm)\\\\n- Location\\\\n\\\\n**Flight data recording (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nPlanes have a multitude of sensors. This sensor data is stored in a black box and also shared with external systems. TimeSeries can help you reconstruct the sequence of events over time, optimize operations and maintenance intervals, improve safety, and provide feedback to the equipment manufacturers about the part quality. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Altitude\\\\n- Flight path\\\\n- Engine temperature\\\\n- Level of vibrations\\\\n- Pressure\\\\n\\\\n**Ship logbooks (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nIt\'s very common to keep track of ship voyages via (digital) logbooks. Use TimeSeries to calculate optimal routes using these metrics:\\\\n\\\\n- Wind (km/h)\\\\n- Ocean conditions (classes)\\\\n- Speed (knots)\\\\n- Location (long, lat)\\\\n\\\\n**Connected car (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nModern cars are exposing several metrics via a standard interface. Use TimeSeries to correlate average fuel consumption with the tire pressure, figure out how long to keep a car in the fleet, determine optimal maintenance intervals, and calculate tax savings by type of the road (taxable vs. nontaxable roads). Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Acceleration\\\\n- Location (long, lat)\\\\n- Fuel level (liter)\\\\n- Distances (km)\\\\n- Speed (km/h)\\\\n- Tire pressure\\\\n- Distance until next maintenance check\\\\n\\\\n**Smart metering (sensor data and IoT)**\\\\n\\\\nModern houses and facilities gather details about energy consumption/production. Use Redis Time Series to aggregate billing based on monthly consumption. Optimize the network by redirecting the energy delivery relative to the fluctuations in need. Provide recommendations on how to improve the energy consumption behavior. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Consumption per location\\\\n- Produced amount of electrical energy per location\\\\n\\\\n**Quality of service (telecom)**\\\\n\\\\nMobile phone usage is increasing, producing a natural growth that just correlates to the increasing number of cellphones. However, there might also be spikes that correlate with specific events (for example, more messages around world championships). \\\\n\\\\nTelecom providers need to ensure that they are providing the necessary infrastructure to deliver the right quality of service. This includes using mini towers for short-term peaks. Use TimeSeries to correlate traffic peaks to specific events, load balance traffic over several towers or mini towers, and predictively plan the infrastructure. Metrics include the amount of traffic per tower.\\\\n\\\\n**Stock trading (finance)**\\\\n\\\\nStock trading is highly automated today. Algorithms, and not just human beings, are trading, from the amount of bids and asks for the trading of a stock to the extreme volumes of trades per second (millions of ops per second). Computer-driven trading requires millisecond response times. It\'s necessary to keep a lot of data points within a very short period of time (for example, price fluctuations per second within a minute). In addition, the long-term history needs to be kept to make statements about trends or for regulatory purposes.  \\\\n\\\\nUse Redis Time Series to identify correlations between the trading behavior and other events (for example, social network posts). Discover a developing market. Detect anomalies to discover insider trades. Example metrics include:\\\\n\\\\n- Exact time and order of a trade by itself\\\\n- Type of the event (trade/bid)\\\\n- The stock price\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.7569,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"6072bd82\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"6072bd82-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redistimeseries 1.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features > Integrations\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"If you want to keep all of your raw data points indefinitely, your data set will grow linearly over time. However, if your use case allows you to have less fine-grained data further back in time, downsampling can be applied. This allows you to keep fewer historical data points by aggregating raw data for a given time window using a given aggregation function. RedisTimeSeries supports downsampling with the following aggregations: avg, sum, min, max, range, count, first and last.\\\\n\\\\nWhen using Redis’ core data structures, you can only retrieve a time series by knowing the exact key holding the time series. Unfortunately, for many time series use cases (such as root cause analysis or monitoring), your application won’t know the exact key it’s looking for. These use cases typically want to query a set of time series that relate to each other in a couple of dimensions to extract the insight you need. You could create your own secondary index with core Redis data structures to help with this, but it would come with a high development cost and require you to manage edge cases to make sure the index is correct.\\\\n\\\\nRedisTimeSeries does this indexing for you based on `field value` pairs (a.k.a labels) you can add to each time series, and use to filter at query time (a full list of these filters is available in our documentation). Here’s an example of creating a time series with two labels (sensor_id and area_id are the fields with values 2 and 32 respectively) and a retention window of 60,000 milliseconds:\\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\nTS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWhen you need to query a time series, it’s cumbersome to stream all raw data points if you’re only interested in, say, an average over a given time interval. RedisTimeSeries follows the Redis philosophy to only transfer the minimum required data to ensure lowest latency. Below is an example of aggregation query over time buckets of 5,000 milliseconds with an aggregation function:  \\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> TS.RANGE temperature:3:32 1548149180000 1548149210000 AGGREGATION avg 5000\\\\n1) 1) (integer) 1548149180000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"26.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n2) 1) (integer) 1548149185000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"27.399999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n3) 1) (integer) 1548149190000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"24.800000000000001\\\\\\"\\\\n4) 1) (integer) 1548149195000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"23.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n5) 1) (integer) 1548149200000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"25.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n6) 1) (integer) 1548149205000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"28\\\\\\"\\\\n7) 1) (integer) 1548149210000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"20\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nRedisTimeSeries comes with several integrations into existing time series tools. One such integration is our [RedisTimeSeries adapter for Prometheus](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-redistimeseries-adapter), which keeps all your monitoring metrics inside RedisTimeSeries while leveraging the entire Prometheus ecosystem.\\\\nFurthermore, we also created direct integration for [Grafana](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/grafana-redistimeseries). [This repository](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-demos) contains a docker-compose setup of RedisTimeSeries, its remote write adaptor, Prometheus and Grafana. It also comes with a set of data generators and pre-built Grafana dashboards.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.3689,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"43b5f91b\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"43b5f91b-005\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/lists.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis lists\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Examples > Capped lists\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Lists are useful for a number of tasks, two very representative use cases\\\\nare the following:\\\\n\\\\n* Remember the latest updates posted by users into a social network.\\\\n* Communication between processes, using a consumer-producer pattern where the producer pushes items into a list, and a consumer (usually a *worker*) consumes those items and executes actions. Redis has special list commands to make this use case both more reliable and efficient.\\\\n\\\\nFor example both the popular Ruby libraries [resque](https://github.com/resque/resque) and\\\\n[sidekiq](https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq) use Redis lists under the hood in order to\\\\nimplement background jobs.\\\\n\\\\nThe popular Twitter social network [takes the latest tweets](http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Real-Time-Delivery-Twitter)\\\\nposted by users into Redis lists.\\\\n\\\\nTo describe a common use case step by step, imagine your home page shows the latest\\\\nphotos published in a photo sharing social network and you want to speedup access.\\\\n\\\\n* Every time a user posts a new photo, we add its ID into a list with [`LPUSH`]().\\\\n* When users visit the home page, we use `LRANGE 0 9` in order to get the latest 10 posted items.\\\\n\\\\nIn many use cases we just want to use lists to store the *latest items*,\\\\nwhatever they are: social network updates, logs, or anything else.\\\\n\\\\nRedis allows us to use lists as a capped collection, only remembering the latest\\\\nN items and discarding all the oldest items using the [`LTRIM`]() command.\\\\n\\\\nThe [`LTRIM`]() command is similar to [`LRANGE`](), but **instead of displaying the\\\\nspecified range of elements** it sets this range as the new list value. All\\\\nthe elements outside the given range are removed.\\\\n\\\\nFor example, if you\'re adding bikes on the end of a list of repairs, but only\\\\nwant to worry about the 3 that have been on the list the longest:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5\\\\n(integer) 5\\\\n> LTRIM bikes:repairs 0 2\\\\nOK\\\\n> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:1\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:2\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe above [`LTRIM`]() command tells Redis to keep just list elements from index\\\\n0 to 2, everything else will be discarded. This allows for a very simple but\\\\nuseful pattern: doing a List push operation + a List trim operation together \\\\nto add a new element and discard elements exceeding a limit. Using \\\\n[`LTRIM`]() with negative indexes can then be used to keep only the 3 most recently added:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> DEL bikes:repairs\\\\n(integer) 1\\\\n> RPUSH bikes:repairs bike:1 bike:2 bike:3 bike:4 bike:5\\\\n(integer) 5\\\\n> LTRIM bikes:repairs -3 -1\\\\nOK\\\\n> LRANGE bikes:repairs 0 -1\\\\n1) \\\\\\"bike:3\\\\\\"\\\\n2) \\\\\\"bike:4\\\\\\"\\\\n3) \\\\\\"bike:5\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe above combination adds new elements and keeps only the 3\\\\nnewest elements into the list. With [`LRANGE`]() you can access the top items\\\\nwithout any need to remember very old data.\\\\n\\\\nNote: while [`LRANGE`]() is technically an O(N) command, accessing small ranges\\\\ntowards the head or the tail of the list is a constant time operation.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.3259,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"6072bd82\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"6072bd82-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redistimeseries 1.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"In RedisTimeSeries, we are introducing a new data type that uses chunks of memory of fixed size for time series samples, indexed by the same [Radix Tree implementation](https://github.com/antirez/rax) as Redis Streams. With Streams, you can create a [capped stream](, effectively limiting the number of messages by count. In RedisTimeSeries, you can apply a retention policy in milliseconds. This is better for time series use cases, because they are typically interested in the data during a given time window, rather than a fixed number of samples.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

Click **Save**.\\\\n\\\\n[Redis Cloud]() does not let you configure RedisTimeSeries manually. However, if you have a Flexible or Annual [subscription](), you can contact [support](https://redis.com/company/support/) to request a configuration change. You cannot change RedisTimeSeries configuration for Free or Fixed subscriptions.\\\\n\\\\nSee [configuration parameters]() in the Develop section for parameter details and compatibility with Redis Software and Redis Cloud.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.0623,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"6072bd82\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"6072bd82-002\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redistimeseries 1.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v1.0.0 (June 2019) > Features > Integrations\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"If you want to keep all of your raw data points indefinitely, your data set will grow linearly over time. However, if your use case allows you to have less fine-grained data further back in time, downsampling can be applied. This allows you to keep fewer historical data points by aggregating raw data for a given time window using a given aggregation function. RedisTimeSeries supports downsampling with the following aggregations: avg, sum, min, max, range, count, first and last.\\\\n\\\\nWhen using Redis’ core data structures, you can only retrieve a time series by knowing the exact key holding the time series. Unfortunately, for many time series use cases (such as root cause analysis or monitoring), your application won’t know the exact key it’s looking for. These use cases typically want to query a set of time series that relate to each other in a couple of dimensions to extract the insight you need. You could create your own secondary index with core Redis data structures to help with this, but it would come with a high development cost and require you to manage edge cases to make sure the index is correct.\\\\n\\\\nRedisTimeSeries does this indexing for you based on `field value` pairs (a.k.a labels) you can add to each time series, and use to filter at query time (a full list of these filters is available in our documentation). Here’s an example of creating a time series with two labels (sensor_id and area_id are the fields with values 2 and 32 respectively) and a retention window of 60,000 milliseconds:\\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\nTS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWhen you need to query a time series, it’s cumbersome to stream all raw data points if you’re only interested in, say, an average over a given time interval. RedisTimeSeries follows the Redis philosophy to only transfer the minimum required data to ensure lowest latency. Below is an example of aggregation query over time buckets of 5,000 milliseconds with an aggregation function:  \\\\n\\\\n```sh\\\\n127.0.0.1:6379> TS.RANGE temperature:3:32 1548149180000 1548149210000 AGGREGATION avg 5000\\\\n1) 1) (integer) 1548149180000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"26.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n2) 1) (integer) 1548149185000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"27.399999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n3) 1) (integer) 1548149190000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"24.800000000000001\\\\\\"\\\\n4) 1) (integer) 1548149195000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"23.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n5) 1) (integer) 1548149200000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"25.199999999999999\\\\\\"\\\\n6) 1) (integer) 1548149205000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"28\\\\\\"\\\\n7) 1) (integer) 1548149210000\\\\n   2) \\\\\\"20\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nRedisTimeSeries comes with several integrations into existing time series tools. One such integration is our [RedisTimeSeries adapter for Prometheus](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-redistimeseries-adapter), which keeps all your monitoring metrics inside RedisTimeSeries while leveraging the entire Prometheus ecosystem.\\\\nFurthermore, we also created direct integration for [Grafana](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/grafana-redistimeseries). [This repository](https://github.com/RedisTimeSeries/prometheus-demos) contains a docker-compose setup of RedisTimeSeries, its remote write adaptor, Prometheus and Grafana. It also comes with a set of data generators and pre-built Grafana dashboards.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 0.6418,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"608370db\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": following the `loadmodule` argument when starting `redis-server`:\\\\n\\\\n  `redis-server --loadmodule ./{modulename}.so [OPT VAL]...`\\\\n\\\\n- Add them as arguments to the `loadmodule` directive in your configuration file (for example, `redis.conf`):\\\\n\\\\n  `loadmodule ./{modulename}.so [OPT VAL]...`\\\\n\\\\n- Use the `MODULE LOAD path [arg [arg ...]]` command.\\\\n\\\\n- Use the `MODULE LOADEX path [CONFIG name value [CONFIG name value ...]] [ARGS args [args ....]]` command.\\\\n\\\\nStarting with Redis 8.0, most time series configuration parameters are runtime parameters.\\\\nWhile you can set runtime parameters at load time, using the Redis `CONFIG` command is easier and works the same way as with Redis runtime configuration parameters.\\\\n\\\\nThis means:\\\\n\\\\n- `CONFIG SET parameter value [parameter value ...] `\\\\n\\\\n  Set one or more configuration parameters.\\\\n\\\\n- `CONFIG GET parameter [parameter ...]`\\\\n\\\\n  Read the current value of one of more parameters.\\\\n\\\\n- `CONFIG REWRITE`\\\\n\\\\n  Rewrite your Redis configuration file (for example, the `redis.conf` file) to reflect the configuration changes.\\\\n\\\\nStarting with Redis 8.0, you can specify time series configuration parameters directly in your Redis configuration file the same way you would for Redis configuration parameters.\\\\n\\\\nOnce a value is set with `CONFIG SET` [TextBlock(text='## Redis TimeSeries 使用场景

Redis TimeSeries 适合以下典型场景：

### 1. 监控与运维（数据中心）
- 服务器 CPU 利用率监控
- 服务间网络延迟追踪
- 存储系统 IO 带宽分析
- 应用响应时间（如 99th percentile）分析

### 2. 环境与气象数据
- 温度、降雨量、日照时长等长期追踪
- 季节性趋势分析和预测
- 多地点数据聚合（如欧洲最低/最高温度）

### 3. IoT 传感器数据
- **飞行数据记录**：高度、航线、引擎温度、振动、压力
- **船舶日志**：风速、海况、航速、位置
- **车联网**：加速度、位置、油耗、轮胎压力、保养里程
- **智能电表**：能源消耗/生产数据

### 4. 金融交易
- 股票价格波动（毫秒级响应）
- 交易行为分析
- 异常检测（如内幕交易）

### 5. 电信服务质量
- 基站流量监控
- 负载均衡
- 峰值预测与基础设施规划

---

## Retention（数据保留）配置

### 配置优先级
1. **Key 级别**：通过 `TS.CREATE` 或 `TS.ALTER` 的 `RETENTION` 参数
2. **全局配置**：`ts-retention-policy` 参数
3. **无保留策略**（默认）

### 配置方法

**Redis 8.0 之前（启动时加载）：**
```bash
redis-server --loadmodule ./redistimeseries.so RETENTION_POLICY 25920000000
```

**Redis 8.0 及以上（运行时配置）：**
```bash
# 设置默认保留 300 天（25920000000 毫秒）
redis> CONFIG SET ts-retention-policy 25920000000

# 持久化到配置文件
redis> CONFIG REWRITE
```

**Key 级别示例：**
```bash
# 创建时指定保留 60 秒
TS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32
```

### 核心特性
- **时间窗口保留**：按毫秒指定保留时长（而非固定样本数）
- **自动过期**：超过保留期的数据自动删除
- **降采样支持**：配合 downsampling 实现长期数据压缩（支持 avg/sum/min/max/range/count/first/last）

---

**来源：**
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/use_cases.md]
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/timeseries/configuration.md > RETENTION_POLICY]
- [/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redistimeseries/redistimeseries-1.0-release-notes.md]')]

## Retention（数据保留）配置

### 配置优先级
1. **Key 级别**：通过 `TS.CREATE` 或 `TS.ALTER` 的 `RETENTION` 参数
2. **全局配置**：`ts-retention-policy` 参数
3. **无保留策略**（默认）

### 配置方法

**Redis 8.0 之前（启动时加载）：**
```bash
redis-server --loadmodule ./redistimeseries.so RETENTION_POLICY 25920000000
```

```bash
# 设置默认保留 300 天（25920000000 毫秒）

```

**Key 级别示例：**
```bash
# 创建时指定保留 60 秒
TS.CREATE temperature RETENTION 60000 LABELS sensor_id 2 area_id 32
```

### 核心特性

query: Compare Count-Min Sketch and Top-K in Redis probabilistic data structures
answer:
Based on the search results from the Redis documentation, here's a comparison of Count-Min Sketch and Top-K probabilistic data structures:

## Overview

**Count-Min Sketch (CMS)** estimates the frequency of elements in a data stream, while **Top-K** identifies the K highest-frequency elements. They have overlapping functionality but serve different use cases.

## Key Differences

### Purpose
- **Count-Min Sketch**: Estimates frequency counts for *any* element you query, useful when you need to track counts across many elements
- **Top-K**: Maintains only the K elements with highest counts, ideal when you only care about the most frequent items

### Data Structure
- **Count-Min Sketch**: Hash table with probabilistic counters (similar to a 2D array with multiple hash functions)
- **Top-K**: Combination of a hash table (for probabilistic counts) + min heap (holding the K highest-count items)

### Algorithm
- **Count-Min Sketch**: Standard CMS algorithm with configurable error rate and probability
- **Top-K**: Based on HeavyKeepers algorithm with "count-with-exponential-decay" strategy, biased against small flows

### Query Capabilities
- **Count-Min Sketch**: Query frequency of *any* element via `CMS.QUERY`
- **Top-K**: Only tracks the top K items; can check if an item is in top-K via `TOPK.QUERY` and list all top-K items via `TOPK.LIST`

### Accuracy Threshold
- **Count-Min Sketch**: Results below `threshold = error × total_count` should be ignored as noise. Only reliable for high-frequency elements
- **Top-K**: High accuracy for the K highest-frequency items specifically

### Deletions
- **Count-Min Sketch**: No deletion support (counters only increment)
- **Top-K**: Items automatically removed from top-K list when displaced by higher-frequency items; supports real-time notifications

## When to Use Each

### Use Count-Min Sketch when:
- You need to query frequencies of many different elements
- You want to track sales volume across thousands of products
- You need approximate counts above a certain threshold
- Example: "What was the sales volume for product X on a given day?"

### Use Top-K when:
- You only care about the most frequent K items
- You need real-time updates when items enter/leave the top-K
- You want to detect anomalies (e.g., DDoS attacks, trending hashtags)
- Example: "What are the 10 most-viewed videos today?" or "Which IP addresses are sending the most requests?"

## Performance
- **Count-Min Sketch**: Optimized for frequent insertions and queries
- **Top-K**: Faster execution times than previous probabilistic algorithms, with `TOPK.LIST` having O(K×log(k)) complexity

## Overlap
As noted in the documentation: "There is, indeed, some overlap with the functionality of Count-Min Sketch, but the two data structures have their differences and should be applied for different use cases."

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/top-k.md > Use case]

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_zjCTz2k8xqIr7jsTEBTjJn', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 4.9495,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"73073dca\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"73073dca-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/top-k.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Top-K\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Use case\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Top K is a probabilistic data structure in Redis Open Source used to estimate the `K` highest-rank elements from a stream.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\"Highest-rank\\\\\\" in this case means \\\\\\"elements with a highest number or score attached to them\\\\\\", where the score can be a count of how many times the element has appeared in the stream - thus making the data structure perfect for finding the elements with the highest frequency in a stream.\\\\nOne very common application is detecting network anomalies and DDoS attacks where Top K can answer the question: Is there a sudden increase in the flux of requests to the same address or from the same IP?\\\\n \\\\nThere is, indeed, some overlap with the functionality of Count-Min Sketch, but the two data structures have their differences and should be applied for different use cases. \\\\n\\\\nThe Redis Open Source implementation of Top-K is based on the [HeavyKeepers](https://www.usenix.org/conference/atc18/presentation/gong) algorithm presented by Junzhi Gong et al. It discards some older approaches like \\\\\\"count-all\\\\\\" and \\\\\\"admit-all-count-some\\\\\\" in favour of a \\\\\\"**count-with-exponential-decay**\\\\\\" strategy which is biased against mouse (small) flows and has a limited impact on elephant (large) flows. This implementation uses two data structures in tandem: a hash table that holds the probabilistic counts (much like the Count-Min Sketch), and a min heap that holds the `K` items with the highest counts. This ensures high accuracy with shorter execution times than previous probabilistic algorithms allowed, while keeping memory utilization to a fraction of what is typically required by a Sorted Set. It has the additional benefit of being able to get real time notifications when elements are added or removed from the Top K list.\\\\n\\\\n**Trending hashtags (social media platforms, news distribution networks)** \\\\n\\\\nThis application answers these questions: \\\\n\\\\n- What are the K hashtags people have mentioned the most in the last X hours? \\\\n- What are the K news with highest read/view count today? \\\\n\\\\nData flow is the incoming social media posts from which you parse out the different hashtags. \\\\n\\\\nThe [`TOPK.LIST`]() command has a time complexity of `O(K*log(k))` so if `K` is small, there is no need to keep a separate set or sorted set of all the hashtags. You can query directly from the Top K itself.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 4.4181,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"5f323784\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"5f323784-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/count-min-sketch.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Count-min sketch\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Examples\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Count-Min Sketch is a probabilistic data structure in Redis Open Source that can be used to estimate the frequency of events/elements in a stream of data.\\\\n\\\\nIt uses a sub-linear space at the expense of over-counting some events due to collisions. It consumes a stream of events/elements and keeps estimated counters of their frequency.\\\\n\\\\nIt is very important to know that the results coming from a Count-Min sketch lower than a certain threshold (determined by the error_rate) should be ignored and often even approximated to zero. So Count-Min sketch is indeed a data-structure for counting frequencies of elements in a stream, but it\'s only useful for higher counts. Very low counts should be ignored as noise.\\\\n\\\\n**Products (retail, online shops)** \\\\n\\\\nThis application answers this question: What was the sales volume (on a certain day) for a product? \\\\n\\\\nUse one Count-Min sketch created per day (period). Every product sale goes into the CMS. The CMS give reasonably accurate results for the products that contribute the most toward the sales. Products with low percentage of the total sales are ignored.\\\\n\\\\nAssume you select an error rate of 0.1% (0.001) with a certainty of 99.8% (0.998). This means you have an error probability of 0.02% (0.002). Your sketch strives to keep the error within 0.1% of the total count of all elements you\'ve added. There\'s a 0.02% chance the error might exceed this—like when an element below the threshold overlaps with one above it. When you add a few items to the CMS and evaluate their frequency, remember that in such a small sample, collisions are rare, as seen with other probabilistic data structures.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n> CMS.INITBYPROB bikes:profit 0.001 0.002\\\\nOK\\\\n> CMS.INCRBY bikes:profit \\\\\\"Smokey Mountain Striker\\\\\\" 100\\\\n(integer) 100\\\\n> CMS.INCRBY bikes:profit \\\\\\"Rocky Mountain Racer\\\\\\" 200 \\\\\\"Cloudy City Cruiser\\\\\\" 150\\\\n1) (integer) 200\\\\n2) (integer) 150\\\\n> CMS.QUERY bikes:profit \\\\\\"Smokey Mountain Striker\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Rocky Mountain Racer\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Cloudy City Cruiser\\\\\\" \\\\\\"Terrible Bike Name\\\\\\"\\\\n1) (integer) 100\\\\n2) (integer) 200\\\\n3) (integer) 150\\\\n4) (integer) 0\\\\n> CMS.INFO bikes:profit\\\\n1) width\\\\n2) (integer) 2000\\\\n3) depth\\\\n4) (integer) 9\\\\n5) count\\\\n6) (integer) 450\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.7685,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"5f323784\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"5f323784-003\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/data-types/probabilistic/count-min-sketch.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Count-min sketch\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Sizing > 2. Probability\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"The `error` parameter will determine the width `w` of your sketch and the probability will determine the number of hash functions (depth `d`). The error rate we choose will determine the threshold above which we can trust the result from the sketch. The correlation is:\\\\n```\\\\nthreshold = error * total_count \\\\n```\\\\nor\\\\n```\\\\nerror = threshold/total_count\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nwhere `total_count` is the sum of the count of all elements that can be obtained from the `count` key of the result of the [`CMS.INFO`]() command and is of course dynamic - it changes with every new increment in the sketch. At creation time you can approximate the `total_count` ratio as a product of the average count you\'ll be expecting in the sketch and the average number of elements.\\\\n\\\\nSince the threshold is a function of the total count in the filter it\'s very important to note that it will grow as  the count grows, but knowing the total count we can always dynamically calculate the threshold. If a result is below it - it can be discarded.\\\\n\\\\n`probability` in this data structure represents the chance of an element that has a count below the threshold to collide with elements that had a count above the threshold on all sketches/depths thus returning a min-count of a frequently occurring element instead of its own.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 2.0579,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"49a1af21\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"49a1af21-011\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisce/redisos-8.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisos 8.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Redis Open Source 8.0.0 (May 2025) > Security fixes (compared to 8.0-RC1)\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"- Name change: Redis Community Edition is now Redis Open Source\\\\n- License change: licensed under your choice of \\\\n  - (a) the Redis Source Available License 2.0 (RSALv2); \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisbloom/redisbloom-2.0-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisbloom 2.0 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v2.0.0 (June 2019)\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"RedisBloom v2.0.3 requires:\\\\n\\\\n- Minimum Redis compatibility version (database): 4.0.0\\\\n- Minimum Redis Enterprise Software version (cluster): 5.0.0\\\\n\\\\n- Performance improvements:\\\\n    - #[95](https://github.com/RedisBloom/RedisBloom/issues/95) Top-K -
